urn:contentItem:5X16-91K1-JCMN-Y29N-00000-00Texas AG Ken Paxton Leads The Way On Google Antitrust Investigation: 'It's Creating National Interest'2019-09-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:15ZLexisNexisTexas AG Ken Paxton Leads The Way On Google Antitrust Investigation: 'It's Creating National Interest'Audrey Conklin

Sep 10, 2019( Conservative Daily News: http://conservativedailynews.com Delivered by Newstex) A total of 50 attorneys general from across the U.S. have signed onto a probe into Google and its potential to stifle market competition. Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, who is leading the investigation, told the Daily Caller News Foundation that the goal of the investigation is to 'have an open, fair and free market.' Google responded to the investigation saying, 'We look forward to showing how we are investing in innovation, providing services that people want, and engaging in robust and fair competition.' Attorneys general from 48 states, Puerto Rico and D.C. on Monday announced a bipartisan antitrust probe into Google and its potential to stifle market competition.

Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, who is leading the investigation, joined a dozen other attorneys general at the U.S. Supreme Court for a Monday press conference, describing concerns that Google holds too much power over the online advertising market. 'It's really compelling that you have the interest of virtually the entire nation coming from different perspectives with their own different concerns about consumers. It's creating international interest,' Paxton explained to the Daily Caller News Foundation.(Article Continues Below Advertisement) WATCH:AGs TAKE ON TECH: Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, along with other state attorneys general, is announcing a multi-state investigation into Big Tech companies. https://t.co/LmE4ztzCS1[1] — NowThis (@nowthisnews) September 9, 2019[2] 'Everybody thinks the internet is free, and it's not,' he explained. 'When you have one player so dominant in the search engine, advertising market it's like a real estate transaction. the buyers, they're on the seller side, they're the auctioneer, and they control the video platform that a lot of people use.'(Article Continues Below Advertisement) Sponsored Content Google responded to the probe in a Friday statement[3], saying, 'It's of course right that governments should have oversight to ensure that all successful companies, including ours, are complying with the law,' but, the investigation 'is not new' for the company. 'We have always worked constructively with regulators and we will continue to do so. We look forward to showing how we are investing in innovation, providing services that people want, and engaging in robust and fair competition,' the statement added. Paxton said Google is 'a very dominant force' in the tech market, which 'allows them to charge premium pricing,' adding that 'it appears they've bought their competition or forced them out by other means.' The goal of the Google investigation, he said, is to 'have an open, fair and free market. If that's what's going on with Google, then fine. But if they're acting in a way that disincentivizes competition and forces people out unfairly, that's a problem.' The probe came three days after New York Attorney General Letitia James announced[4] an antitrust investigation with eight other attorneys general from Colorado, Florida, Iowa, Nebraska, North Carolina and Ohio into Facebook for similar monopoly concerns. James's investigation will look into 'Facebook's dominance in the industry and the potential anticompetitive conduct stemming from that dominance,' according to a statement[5] from her office. Paxton said he is interested in joining James's probe and applauded her for the effort. NetChoice President Carl Szabo, whotestified[6] in a July 16 congressional hearing titled 'Online Platforms and Market Power' and previously told[7] the DCNF that an investigation into Google or Facebook would be a 'tech witch hunt,' said he thinks Paxton 'appears to have an open mind about this investigation.' 'Some [attroneys general] already have a conclusion, and then they look for the facts afterward, and that sets a dangerous precedent for any law enforcement body,' he added. Szabo also said, however, that he thinks the investigation is unnecessary. 'What you're seeing is kind of a pile-on where there's no real disincentive for a state AG to put their name on the investigation. A lot of people can go out searching for things like El Dorado and invest their time into looking for something that just doesn't exist,' he said. 'If you take a mere three minutes to think about the arguments for an antitrust case against Facebook and Google, they just don't exist. There's robust competition, and direct competitors can all simultaneously be monopolies. The American public overwhelmingly believes that on the list of things the government should look into, big tech is not a priority,' he continued. Competitive Enterprise Institute (CEI) Center for Technology Associate Director and Innovation Jessica Melugin[8] similarly said in a statement[9], 'These state attorneys general are expanding the power of their office and stretching the limits of what constitutes an antitrust violation. This sort of high-profile activism may benefit state AGs' political ambitions, but impose harmful costs on consumers, businesses, and the economy.' 'The only consistency among the various state, federal agency, and congressional antitrust investigations into big tech seems to be that none of them have much to do with the well-established test for antitrust law in the U.S.; consumer harm,' Melugin added. Paxton conversely made the point that the attorneys general he is working with to look into Google are simply 'in discovery mode,' adding, 'We want to understand what the issues are if there are any before we say what we think the remedy should be.' He said that if there really is no case for antitrust, then those who believe the investigation is unnecessary 'have nothing to worry about.' 'This is an investigation,' he told the DCNF. 'Hopefully legitimately cooperative with this. Best case is, they're not acting in anti-competitive ways, and there is an opportunity for competitors to offer consumers the same products, and it will all be good.' U.S. Attorney General William Barr also announced a Justice Department probe[10] into Google and its potential to unlawfully stifle market competition in June, making it the first such investigation since the Federal Trade Commission closed[11] its longest-running probe into Google in 2013 without any penalties against the company.Content created by The Daily Caller News Foundation is availablewithout charge to any eligible news publisher that can provide a large audience. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XSG-H441-JCDY-T0PN-00000-00Texas and Google battle over experts in antitrust case2019-12-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:15ZLexisNexisA sectionPg. A20Texas and Google battle over experts in antitrust caseTony Romm

Investigators say in filing that tech firm is trying to hinder states' probe

Texas investigators are defending their decision to employ some of Google's longtime foes as part of an antitrust probe into the search giant, saying in a court filing that the recent legal objections raised by the company threaten to 'severely compromise' states' scrutiny.

At issue are a number of consultants retained by Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, who is leading an inquiry into Google's ad business that's backed by 50 other attorneys general. The experts include people who previously have worked on behalf of Google's rivals, including News Corp., in antitrust battles around the world.

In October, Google lawyers asked a Texas court to limit those consultants' access to the tech giant's secrets. Almost two months later, Texas officials told a judge in Travis County that Google's requests are highly problematic, serving only to try to block much-needed experts from contributing in a complicated matter. The Washington Post obtained the documents, dated Dec. 9, through an open-records request.

'Google's Petition, under the guise of protecting confidential information, seeks to frustrate the [Office of the Attorney General's] statutorily-prescribed investigative authority by severely hampering the [office's] lawful ability to employ the services of experts, consultants, and others for purposes of the investigation,' lawyers for Texas argued in their filing.

In response, Google spokesman Jose Castaneda in a statement described the attorney general's hires as an 'extraordinarily irregular arrangement,' adding it is 'only fair to have assurances that our confidential business information won't be shared with competitors or vocal complainants.'

The back-and-forth between Texas and Google reflects the high stakes in what's likely to be a long, sweeping antitrust review of Google's business practices. The probe, announced in September, is focused on Google's online-advertising operation, which helped generate $117 billion for the company last year. Paxton and his Democratic and Republican colleagues are probing whether Google's ad practices harm a wide array of businesses, including news publishers, and result in higher prices, worse service or fewer choices for consumers online.

The states' effort is one of several major antitrust probes into Google in the United States and around the world: In Washington, the Justice Department similarly is scrutinizing the company, while House lawmakers have pored over Google records as part of a review of big tech and federal competition laws. Abroad, competition watchdogs in the United Kingdom have opened their own review into Facebook and Google. On Wednesday, they issued an interim report finding the companies 'may have become entrenched with negative consequences for the people and businesses who use these services every day.'

In response, Google has defended its practices on each of those fronts, claiming it has actually created competition, not limited it. But the company has taken special exception with Texas and Paxton in response to two experts the Lone Star State tapped this year to study the matter.

The first, Cristina Caffarra, is a top competition expert at Charles River Associates, where she has represented clients including the Rupert Murdoch-backed News Corp., which previously has called for a breakup of Google. Caffarra has been most active in Europe, where regulators have repeatedly fined Google for violating competition laws.

The second expert, Eugene Burrus, has been behind lawsuits and investigations into Google's business practices, the tech giant contended in its October filing. Much like Caffarra, Google has expressed concerns with his selection, including fears he could take the knowledge gleaned from the Texas probe and battle the tech giant again in the future.

In October, Google urged a judge to impose an order on Caffarra, Burrus and others from disclosing certain information or working for any of Google's rivals for a year after the probe concludes.

In their response, Paxton's team argued it had already sought to protect Google's confidential information. The attorney general's team said its contracts 'expressly provide that any information obtained via the investigation is not to be shared with any third party or used for any purpose other than the investigation.'

The order that Google proposed, however, would be 'so expansive that it would severely compromise the [office's] ability to hire an expert, court reporter, or even graphic support for this investigation,' Paxton's lawyers said.

And Texas charged that Google essentially would 'gate an investigative process which is, by its nature, fluid depending on the evidence that is uncovered.' In doing so, Texas offered the latest indication that the 51 attorneys general involved in the investigation could easily expand their focus well beyond advertising.

'As the subject matter of the investigation is initially broad (Google's potentially anticompetitive conduct), the specific behavior and acts at issue will likely change and evolve as the investigation progresses,' lawyers for Paxton wrote.

tony.romm@washpost.com

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S2Y-WG51-JB20-G4PV-00000-00Texas, Arizona, New Mexico Pledge Hundreds Of National Guard; Mark Zuckerberg Testifies Before Congress On Facebook Data Breach2018-04-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:15ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTRon DeSantisNEWSDomestic041001cb.229Texas, Arizona, New Mexico Pledge Hundreds Of National Guard; Mark Zuckerberg Testifies Before Congress On Facebook Data BreachCharles Payne, Lou Dobbs, Gregg Jarrett, Ed Rollins

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good evening, everybody. The Dems, the left wing national media, the deep state, all aided and abetted by RINO Senators have escalated. They're all out assault on the President of the United States. The Republicans in name only haven't the guts to stand with or support President Trump. Instead they cower before the powerful establishment interest who mean to destroy the Trump presidency no matter all that he has achieved, no matter all that he has done for America and Americans. This historic President has been investigated by the special counsel and the FBI for 22 months in a row. And not so much as an iota of evidence has been produced against him. And make no mistake whatsoever.

The globalist elites, the entrenched establishment are now desperate and making no pretense of adhering to law or standards of decency. Senators Mitch McConnell, John Cornyn, Chuck Grassley, Thom Tillis, among the RINOs working against President Trump, not for him, not for the Republican Party but for their money masters on K Street seeking to protect Special Counsel Robert Mueller and preserve at all costs his failed and now desperate investigation. Congressman Ron DeSantis has been pushing for Mueller's firing since last summer. He joins us here in just moments.

And also tonight, Texas, Arizona, New Mexico, those states announcing they're sending a combined 1600 National Guard troops to the border. California, the only border state prioritizing the rights of illegal immigrants ahead of the interest and rights of the the American citizens. We'll have a full report for you from the border.

And stocks today soaring. I said soaring. China's President offering the United States new trade concessions. China's Xi vowing to lower Chinese tariffs against American and Western products to cut Chinese tariffs on vehicles to allow more foreign competition and better protect foreign intellectual property. Worthy of note, many in the business press haven't apologized yet for sensationalizing the higher Trump tariffs that made all of this possible and they have certainly not acknowledged President Trump's success in moving talks with President Xi forward because of Presidents Trump and Xi, there is now at hand a real opportunity for balanced reciprocal trade between the United States and China and the world. We take up all of that here tonight.

Our top story, Special Counsel Robert Mueller, Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein making a mockery of the judicial system. And President Trump today firing back at the unprecedented FBI raid on the New York office and residence of his personal attorney, Michael Cohen. The President tweeted this, attorney-client privilege is dead and a total witch-hunt. The New York Times today reported deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein personally approved the FBI raid and Federal prosecutors in Manhattan obtained a search warrant after receiving a referral in part from Special Counsel Robert Mueller. This is the same Rod Rosenstein who believes he can oversee the obstruction of justice investigation into the firing of former FBI Director James Comey even though it was Rosenstein who wrote the memorandum recommending that President Trump fire Comey, the same Rosenstein who signed off on FISA Court warrants that resulted in the Obama administration spying on the Trump presidential campaign.

The same Rosenstein who set the scope for Mueller's special counsel probe in May of last year. The Cohen raid is a clear sign of Mueller's desperation after he's failed to find any evidence of collusion, his original mandate as special counsel. The corrupt leadership of the Justice Department obviously believes Mueller's investigation must now be unfettered. RINO Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley doesn't criticize, he doesn't call for constraint by the special counsel, instead this is what Chairman Grassley, who's been in the Swamp for almost 40 years, said today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CHUCK GRASSLEY (R-IA), CHAIRMAN, SENATE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: I have confidence in Mueller, the President ought to have confidence in Mueller and I think to answer your question, it would be suicide for the President to want to talk about firing Mueller.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Our first guest tonight, outraged over the FBI's stunning double standard, the special counsel targeting Cohen while Hillary Clinton's blatant violations of campaign finance laws are ignored all together by both the FBI and the Justice Department. He also says contempt proceedings need to occur now in the wake of the DOJ and FBI's failure to comply with Congress' constitutional right to oversight. Joining us tonight, Congressman Ron Desantis, member of several key committees, that include Oversight and Government Reform, Foreign Affairs and Judiciary. He is also the leading Republican candidate to be governor of the great State of Florida. Great to have you with us, Congressman.

Let's start - let's start with first of all, Grassley. He's been sitting in Washington in the Senate approaching four decades. And he has confidence in Mueller. Are you kidding me? What in the world is this man thinking?

REP. RON DESANTIS (R), FLORIDA: Lou, I think about how they handled say Cheryl Mills who was Hillary Clinton's attorney. They had her sitting in, you know, on the -- on the interview. They weren't raiding Cheryl Mills' office even though Cheryl Mills, you know, there were some issues with Cheryl Mills. And in this instance, to go to this extreme length for what's the underlying offense? They say a campaign finance violation? What about the Clinton campaign? They did millions and millions of dollars to the Perkins Coie Law Firm who then paid Fusion GPS. So that when they filed their FEC compliance reports, there was no trace of Fusion GPS or the dossier or any of that. So they camouflaged those payments. You're not supposed to do that.

Has Fusion GPS been raided? Has Perkins Coie been raided? And so the double standard here is really, really troubling Lou and it just seems that ever since the special counsel was appointed it was try to figure out whatever we can find any way and just throw it against the wall and hope it sticks. That's not the way you want law enforcement to go.

DOBBS: Well, law enforcement, I don't even know if there is such a thing left within the FBI or the Department of Justice. It is a -- the special counsel investigation is a political persecution, it's no longer an investigation. This is a joke. The people leading it are a joke. We're talking about 13 of 17 attorneys who are Democrats and I'm talking about -- I'm talking about ideologically left wing Democrats. These are not just passing Kiwanis Luncheon. These folks are committed. And this tells us all we need to know.

Why isn't there some standard either by the Department of Justice or at least by the leadership of the House and the Congress as to who can be involved in this investigation? There's just no question. This is corruption at its worst.

DESANTIS: We've raised that in the Congress, a handful of us has. Not the whole leadership, but you look at somebody like an Andrew Weissmann, not only is he a big Democrat, not only is he have a checkered reputation, but he was in Hillary Clinton's election party in 2016. He's reported to have made derogatory comments about President Trump before the special counsel investigation started. Why would you put somebody like him on this because when you're doing these things, the American public needs to have confidence and then here's the problem with all of this, Lou.

At this point, you have half of the country, the people that voted for Donald Trump, they're not going to have confidence in any type of negative outcome in this thing. That confidence is shot. And so I just think that this is doing a lot of damage to the country at this point.

DOBBS: It's doing a lot of damage to the country. It could be -- that damage though could be very specific and much broader based than half the country. We are dealing in some -- we have a President who is contending with so many perils from so many directions in foreign policy. It's extraordinary that the -- frankly Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell are nothing more than the stooges of K Street, the Chamber of Commerce, the business round table, and the establishment of this country. And they are behaving abominably.

DESANTIS: Well, what we're trying to do now this week, I mean, you mentioned it in your lead in, there are all of these documents we asked for for a long time, including just the two-page document that kicked off the so-called collusion investigation. Nnunes has been asking for that for months and months. And so here's the thing. Ei8ther they turned it over or we immediately have to move the hold these people in contempt, Lou. We can't just keep playing this game back and forth, running out the clock. The American people are entitled to this. We're entitled to this in the Congress and if we're not willing to put our constitutional muscle behind this request, they were going to continue to be treated like a lackluster institution that too often we are.

DOBBS: Tomorrow is that deadline, April 11th. That was extended by both committees. I mean, what are the odds that the deadline will be met and what are the odds that you can muster enough courage, enough principle, enough integrity and enough fire in the House of Representatives to actually move forward and hold officials of the corrupt Justice Department and FBI in contempt?

DESANTIS: So I'm not holding my breath that the -- that the deadline will be met and I don't think anyone should be holding their breath for that. And so I think it will be time to pull the trigger on contempt for these officials because they've stonewalled months and months and months. And think about the difference in behavior in terms of them responding when they're investigating their conduct in terms of the dossier and all of that. How slow they are. But then look how quick they are to go raid Michael Cohen's office when it suits them or how quick they are -- they're probing this donation, the Trump's charity from the Ukrainian businessman, it was 150,000. He gave millions of dollars to the Clinton Foundation. They're not raiding the foundation, they're not -- they're not probing that. So, now is the time to act and we can't have them living under different rules than they're applying to the rest of the country.

DOBBS: It seems to me, congressman, that I have to tell you, we're listening to Mitch McConnell talk about the special counsel as if he wanted to have both arms around him, not just one, instead of stand with the President and demand a higher level of conduct of the special counsel. We don't even hear from Speaker Ryan. All of this could be shut down by the House of Representatives, could it not, if it simply said no more money will be appropriated for the special counsel. Why isn't there a level of integrity, a level of just outrage about the conduct of the Justice Department and the leadership of the Republican Party?

DESANTIS: There was an effort I think for members and I've actually tried to do it too to sunset the special counsel, put up or shut up. But with the omnibus bill, Lou, they packed it in and ran it through in like 12 hours. So there was no amendment, no opportunity for any rank and file member to participate. And so that was a deliberate choice to green light the funding for this thing going forward, at least until the end of the fiscal year. And I think -- I think that's a mistake. We could put constraints on it. If Rosenstein is not willing to do that, we could do it with the power of the purse.

DOBBS: Could have done it.

DESANTIS: Should have done it.

DOBBS: Amen. Congressman, thank you for your leadership there in Washington. Desperately needed. We appreciate everything you're doing. Thanks so much.

DESANTIS: Thanks, Lou.

DOBBS: Up next. Special Counsel Mueller now targeting a Ukrainian oligarch. Gregg Jarrett joins me here next. We take up the witch-hunt. Stay with us.

DOBBS: Special Counsel Mueller is reportedly investigating now a $150,000 payment that a Ukrainian billionaire paid the Trump Foundation. But the real collusion that Mueller might be investigating would focus on the Clintons, the same oligarch is a long-time donor to the Clinton Foundation. He's given some $13 million to the Clinton Foundation since 2006. As far as we know, not even a mild hint of curiosity about those donations. Joining me now, Fox News Legal Analyst Greg Jarrett. You know, that becomes the theme here, doesn't it? There is a way in which President Trump is treated, there's a way in which Hillary Clinton is treated. There is a way in which President Trump is treated and there is another way that President Obama is treated without raising so much as the prospect of an investigation.

GREGG JARRETT, FOX NEWS LEGAL ANALYST: If Donald Trump so much as sneezes, it's a crime. If Hillary Clinton sells out America's vital uranium assets and receives roughly at the same time about $140 million from Russia, that's, you know, oh, it's a wonderful foundation. It's a charity she runs and so forth. Ignoring the fact that her husband made $105 million while she was secretary of state, the majority of it coming from foreign governments that she was dealing with.

DOBBS: Well, speaking of Uranium One, part of that was an adjunct speaking fee for the former President Bill Clinton in Moscow --

JARRETT: Half a million bucks.

DOBBS: -- of a half a million dollars. No one seems interested in these elements. And this is such a obvious profound partisan driven investigation. I think this has risen to the level of a persecution. It's a political persecution and the Republican Party, the RINO leadership here, my god, Greg. I -- this is --

JARRETT: They should be outraged, but they aren't.

DOBBS: I mean, the American people are sitting here watching this and can't even believe it.

JARRETT: Well, you know, they're deaf, dumb and blind. I mean, that's the best description I have for McConnell and Paul Ryan.

DOBBS: Well, they're may be willfully so. The truth is they sold out. They've sold out a long time ago toying to establishment, to the K Street, to yes, the Chamber of Commerce, the business roundtable and they're the only masters that they recognize now.

JARRETT: The tragedy is what we saw unfold yesterday, going in and seizing the documents that are largely privileged of a lawyer, really to me is one of the most shameful episodes in American legal history. Yes, there's an exception. But what they did is they went in there and they just carted away just about everything. We're supposed to trust that a third person clean team or firewall is going to protect the attorney-client privilege. I -- trust me, I've been a lawyer for about 40 years now. It's not going to happen that way.

DOBBS: Yes. And there is no way that you ascribe a -- clean is the adjective of preference --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: -- within the Justice Department. America, people think and understand what obviously the leadership of the Republican Party doesn't. What we have is a toxic corrupt Justice Department and an FBI whose leadership is rancid with political corruption.

JARRETT: And Mueller and Rosenstein, who are heading up this whole thing, the President was right when he said this is the most conflicted group of people he's ever seen. I mean, Mueller has not one but two disqualifying conflicts of interest and under the law it's mandatory that he recuse himself. Instead he stuck up his middle finger at the justice system. He didn't care. Rosenstein, he is a witness, he is a prosecutor, he is an investigator and basically judge and jury all rolled into one. And again - -

DOBBS: And should be under investigation himself for writing a letter that the President --

JARRETT: Right.

DOBBS: -- read and decided that he agreed with.

JARRETT: This is the definition of corruption. If you look up the word in the dictionary, should have photos of Mueller, Rosenstein and James Comey.

DOBBS: Maybe one of these days, you know, you've got to believe in the American way, that shall come to pass because without it the Republic is going to be deeply threatened beyond even where we are today. Tomorrow, the deadline to produce the 1.2 million documents to meet the deadline set by House Intelligence Committee Chair Devin Nunes. Talking earlier with Congressman DeSantis, he doesn't believe any of us should be holding our breath.

JARRETT: No.

DOBBS: And he believes we move straight to contempt if they do not make the deadline tomorrow.

JARRETT: In a fair and just world, contempt citations would be filed tomorrow. But it is probably not going to happen because Congress is slow- footed. Look at how long they waited. They issued these subpoenas in August, what is that, eight months ago?

DOBBS: Well, they were to produce the documents five months ago. That was when they first issued the order.

JARRETT: Right.

DOBBS: And now we're looking at an extension here from the first -- the original date was last week and now we're talking about tomorrow.

JARRETT: They should have moved for a contempt five months ago at the deadline. If you don't meet the -- if you don't meet the deadline, Lou, or I don't meet the deadline, we are held in contempt of court and they throw us in the (INAUDIBLE) within 24 hours.

DOBBS: Well, and I don't where they're going to throw the Republican Party or what's left of because when the American people watch this and there is no contempt of Congress filed against the Justice Department, the FBI leadership and they don't stand up for a President who is working harder than anyone in Washington.

JARRETT: Right.

DOBBS: There's going to be hell to pay.

JARRETT: Well, the approval rating of Congress hovers right around 11, 12 percent. And there's a good reason for that. They deserve it.

DOBBS: I suspect it's a little inflated. Greg, thanks so much. Gregg Jarrett.

JARRETT: All right.

DOBBS: Be sure to vote in our poll tonight. The question is, do you believe the Department of Justice and FBI will have to be completely purged before we can be returned to a nation of law and order? Cast your vote on Twitter @LouDobbs, follow me on Twitter @LouDobbs, like me on Facebook, follow me on Instagram @LouDobbsTonight.

And on Wall Street today, stocks soaring as Chinese President Xi Jinping agreed to open China's markets and cut tariffs proving Wall Street analysts and economists who predicted a trade war had no idea as usual what they were talking about. None at all. The Dow up 429 points, the S&P up 44, the NASDAQ 144 points. It's what we call a good day on Wall Street and a good day for America. Volume on the big board 3.6 billion.

President Trump's fair trade policies could have an enormous impact. Last quarter -- no one else is going to tell you this but we are going to make a point of telling you this. Last quarter the U.S. trade deficit cut 1.6 percentage points off economic growth, meaning that with better deals, that is with President Trump's balanced and reciprocal trade, we would have had a growth rate in the fourth quarter of just over four percent. It came in at 2.9 as a result of the deficit. U.S. producer prices rose more than expected in March.

We're pleased to tell you. Boosted by rising healthcare and food costs. I'm most especially pleased to tell you energy cost dropped by two percent. A reminder to listen to my reports three times a day Coast to Coast on the Salem Radio Network. Up next. Zuckerberg, it's something of an apology sip. We take up the need to regulate big tech. Ed Rollins joins me here next.

DOBBS: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg testifying before a joint Senate hearing today but he was not under oath. Irrespective of that, listen to some of the leading absurdities that Zuckerberg felt well, quite confident uttering, including the idea that Facebook should be able -- well, to police itself.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO, FACEBOOK: As I've said a number of times today, I think we need to take a broader view of our responsibility around privacy than just what is mandated in the current law. I think the real question as the internet becomes more important in people's lives is what is the right regulation not whether there should be --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: But you as a company welcome regulation?

ZUCKERBERG: I think if it's the right regulation, then yes.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Do you think the Europeans have it right?

ZUCKERBERG: I think that they get things right.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Joining me now, former Reagan White House Political Director, Great America PAC Chairman, Fox Business political analyst, my friend Ed Rollins.

ED ROLLINS, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Thank you.

DOBBS: And it is great to have you here. And what did you think of young Zuck contending with half of the power of the Senate?

ROLLINS: First of all, it's nice to see him in a suit. He's probably hasn't had a suit on since his first communion, he's catholic. Secondly, I think the idea that they're going to regulate themselves is absurd. They have taken all of this privacy information that people have given them, they never once said they could discloses that to the public or to consumers and they've done that and I think to a certain extent they've got -- I think the government has to regulate them. I think they have to basically control what they -- not how they make their profits but how they -- what they do with people's information.

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Well what they're doing is they're trying to regulate the users rather than themselves. That's quite a different statement. And they have been decidedly anti-conservative and pro-liberal. And we watched The Daily Caller reporting, that quite a few people of from the Obama administration and from the Clinton administration have made their way to the top of the upper echelons of Facebook.

ROLLINS: They have and they clearly have used that material that's in there, that information to create their political organizations both Clinton's political organizations certain even more so the Obama administration. And you just have to basically people know what's going to happen, you want to submit data here then just understand they're going to sell it to somebody in. That's wrong.

DOBBS: The political issue is a profound one and that is, are we going to tax the Internet? Should transaction, should revenue be taxed on from the web at the same levels as in brick-and-mortar transactions?

ROLLINS: Well the bottom line if you make a profit you get taxed and no matter what you do and they should too. They should not be any different, they're an interstate worldwide consumer now not an inner state provider a consumer and I think they should be taxed.

DOBBS: But this is also Facebook and then Twitter --

ROLLINS: All of it.

DOBBS: -- other very powerful Amazon, are very powerful organizations and they're spending a lot of money lobbying to assure that they move forward with as few taxes as possible, which is fair and it's the American Way. But what is not fair is when something as powerful as Facebook has such an impact that it is deciding whose voices will be heard, in what order, in what priority not unlike Google and Alphabet. There needs to be an assurance of regulatory constraint against the mad partisan impulses that right now are ribboning a social media.

ROLLINS: Well, having done campaigns for 50 years they have changed the way we do campaigns in America. And so, you have to have -- you have to have a fairness to it. You can't let Democrats have the advantage or Republicans have the advantage. Whatever they're doing, whatever they're providing should be provided go both sides.

DOBBS: In the end, well, in fairness defined as equal access to the platform to government. (INAUDIBLE) then let it be decided. That this business about shutting down. Conservative voices is extraordinary.

The president has pulled off another extraordinary moment and that is President Xi announcing he will open China to Western products and services by cutting tariffs, reducing barriers and protecting foreign intellectual property rights as he does so.

ROLLINS: Well we've talked many, many nice about all the things that the president has done, and everybody sort of poopoo that he could do this when he promised he was going to do this in the course of the campaign. And I would argue that it's people on the other side now know he's a forceful leader and he's going to do it. When he says he's going to do something's going to do it. So, if you want to be on his good side then obviously if you're the head of China you want to be on his good side.

DOBBS: I have to say, I'm embarrassed for the business press, particularly the business press, the political press we stay embarrassed about, right? But the business press doesn't seem to understand basic economics and tonight we pointed out again, they're a trade deficit cuts into a nation's economic royalists. Reduces GDP squanders well. And when you think about that, that should be reported every month.

ROLLINS: Should be.

DOBBS: And I haven't seen a news organization report that element in that impact, that equation between a trade deficit and a reduced GDP growth rate.

ROLLINS: Well they don't even want to give them benefit of the doubt. They don't even want to basically hear his arguments, they want to dump all of the arguments before he's even able he talks about.

DOBBS: But these are craven, cowardly and I -- and frankly incompetent group of reporters. I'm talking about the political reporters that are accompanying this president. Some of them are terrific but I have to say at large, they're an embarrassment to the craft.

ROLLINS: But they're embarrassed by Trump. 90 percent of them like the Justice Department.

DOBBS: What the hell. What are they've got to be embarrassed about? What have they ever done?

ROLLINS: 90 percent of them and I've traveled with them and I've been around him for a long time or like the Justice Department lawyers 90 percent of them are Democrats or anti-Trump. So, anything Trump tries to do they're going to be against.

DOBBS: Well I'm sure that our friends in the press and there are so many of them. Will those liberals, those are mostly liberals are they?

ROLLINS: Mostly.

DOBBS: OK, well we want to extend the season's greetings to them nonetheless. Ed Rollins thank you so much.

ROLLINS: Thank you.

DOBBS: Appreciate it. The nation's governors are mobilizing, responding to the president's call to protect our borders. One state conspicuously silent. You'll never guess which one, yes you will. We'll be right back.

DOBBS: The states of Texas, Arizona and New Mexico are answering president Trump's call to secure the border. FOX News National Correspondent William La Jeunesse in Phoenix tonight with our report.

(BEGIN VIDEO TAPE)

WILLIAM LA JEUNESSE, FOX NEWS NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: A week after President Trump asked for 4,000 National Guardsmen to secure the border, three states answered the call. New Mexico, Texas and Arizona.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GOVERNOR DOUG DUCEY (R), ARIZONA: I'm here to announce the deployment of the National Guard to the border.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LA JEUNESSE: But other states like Oregon and Montana refused to offer their Guard to serve. While California Governor Jerry Brown says he's still reviewing the president's request. If he refused as the President does have the authority to nationalize the Guard. Typically used when troops are sent overseas or to national disasters.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. STEVE STIVERS (R) OHIO: The easiest thing to do would be to choose to put them on a title 10 status but you know, with almost half a million folks in the National Guard across the country the easier thing to do is to work with states who are willing to serve.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LA JEUNESSE: But deployment doesn't necessarily mean a rival. National Guard officials say there's paperwork, processing, medical check-ups, where will they live, most important matching skills. The Border Patrol needs will determine where each Guardsman will be sent. That officials say takes time.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGADIER GENERAL JOHN HOEFERT, NATIONAL GUARD, ARIZONA: We're looking at a request for assistance up to about five to six hundred individual augmentees. Who will help us put badges back to the border that's the whole goal of this mission.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LA JEUNESSE: In Santa Teresa New Mexico a primary corridor for drugs and human smuggling, the Border Patrol welcomes the help.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

AARON HULL, SECTOR CHIEF, U.S. BORDER PATROL: They have a variety capabilities that we can use. Pickily things like aerial detection are important to us given the size of the border.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LA JEUNESSE: The National Guard is sending drones and helicopters to track and apprehend immigrants. Larger Black Hawks can drop agents and remote canyons of capability the patrol has in short supply.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HOEFERT: When you look at the engineering things that need to be done. The grubbing operations, clearing roads, all that. We're looking at how we package those capabilities together.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LA JEUNESSE: Guardsmen will also monitor multiple video feeds that come in from cameras sensors and radar.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DUCEY: Do we stop the flow of illegal Drugs? Do we stop the flow of human trafficking? Can we stop the illegal migrants from coming over?

REP. JOE CROWLEY (D), NEW YORK: A very provocative move but at the same time it's not really solving the problem.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LA JEUNESSE: Now if history is any guide enforcement, one area tends to Bush illegal traffic to another, meaning could deterrence in Arizona and Texas redirect smugglers to the sanctuary of California? Posing the question. Will the president federalized troops in the Golden State over Governor Browns objection? Lou.

(END VIDEO TAPE)

DOBBS: William, thank you very much. William La Jeunesse. Up next that caravan of illegal immigrants in Mexico fowling to cross our Southern border. Congressman Paul Gosar of the Arizona joins us here next. We're coming right back.

DOBBS: Arizona's Supreme Court has ruled DACA recipients will no longer be able to receive in-state tuition rates at Arizona colleges. The high court decision affects more than 2,000 DACA recipients who were paying in-state rates. Organizers for that caravan of illegal immigrants apparently trying to cross our border saying some 200 still plan to seek -- to cross the border with Mexico as of right now. The illegal immigrants from Central America are in Mexico City. Joining us tonight, Congressman Paul Gosar, member of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee. And Congressman, it is great to see you. Your reaction to the Arizona Supreme Court ruling on in-state tuition for DACA recipients.

REP. PAUL GOSAR (R), ARIZONA: They got it right, Lou. It was unanimous against you know, the -- allowing the DACA recipients to getting in-state. They're not even in-state, they're out of state and they shouldn't be even getting that aspect because they're actually illegal in this country. So they got it right. But I'm sure it's not over. I'm sure this will be appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court.

DOBBS: And troops moving -- federal troops, the National Guard moving to the border with Mexico. We're looking at some numbers here and I'd like to share these with the audience. What we've seen happen is the surge in illegal immigration. In addition to that, the drugs, heroin, marijuana, cocaine, methamphetamines all raising, up 70 percent -- heroin is up 70 percent from a year ago, cocaine up almost 50 percent, methamphetamines up 25 percent and it still remains, the Mexican border separates us from a country that is also providing the majority of marijuana. Do you believe that this show of force that the President has ordered will be successful in stopping the drug smuggling?

GOSAR: I think this is a great start because there's something different this time and that is he's negotiating NAFTA at that current aspect. Wouldn't it be nice to say, listen, NAFTA goes away if you don't uphold our rule of law and start supporting us? You know, if you look back at history, Mexico hasn't been a good neighbor during World War I, even in the communist era of Cuba. So from that standpoint, maybe it's time to get tough on trade and that a little different though what's transpiring right now. I think having our military down on the border, our National Guard is going to actually help. We're not catching and releasing anymore so we've got to start following through. I think it's a great start.

DOBBS: By order of the President signing an executive order to end that. Well, let's hope that you're right, that things are going to move. This -- the latest maneuver by the Special Counsel and his agents in the FBI, raiding the President's personal attorney's home, his office, your real quick thoughts if we may.

GOSAR: This has nothing to do with Russia. This shows that this is totally out of bounds. It's time for Rod Rosenstein to go. It's time to impeach him and start putting the parameters back on what we actually asked for the special prosecutor. Rod Rosenstein has been an embarrassment in this aspect and it's time to go.

DOBBS: OK. And your conference and Republican Party has -- and your leadership, Speaker Ryan have the guts to actually do that?

GOSAR: Well, you know, we're going to call it into question because you know, at this point in time, you know, when you look at the sanctity of client-attorney relationships and the total violation here, this shows that Mueller has no intention of looking just at the Russia aspect which he was entitled to do. But now he wants to take away the Presidency because he doesn't agree that Trump should be the president. That's the whole mantra of this whole thing, Lou. And so it's time to start calling the cards into question and Congress has the oversight ability to do so.

DOBBS: All right. Well, we'll see. Congressman Gosar, good to have you with us as always.

GOSAR: Thanks, Lou. Always a pleasure.

DOBBS: China's President Xi and President Trump, well, they're having a meeting of the minds on trade, proving all of those Wall Street analysts and economics and did I mention the business press absolutely wrong? We'll take up the President's victory on trade. National Review Columnist and bestselling author Victor Davis Hanson joins us here next.

DOBBS: President Xi Jinping is opening up China to U.S. and western exports largely because President Trump took a strong stance on trade calling for balanced and reciprocal trade specifically between China and the United States, speaking at a business conference today in China. President Xi promised to cut auto tariffs, to improve intellectual property protections for foreign competitors. Joining us tonight, Hoover Institution Senior Fellow, bestselling author, and Author of the new book, The Second World Wars, How The First Global Conflict Was Fought And Won. It is great to have you back with us Victor. Great to see you. Let's start with first what appears to be a profound breakthrough in the trade discussions between China and the United States.

VICTOR DAVIS HANSON, SENIOR FELLOW, HOOVER INSTITUTION: Well, I think it's part of a larger texture that the so-called establishment thinks that Trump is the aberration where in fact, the existing trade protocols we had with China were the aberrations. So this is a return to normality, at least a small step. China was demanding of American companies sort of what the Third Reich did in the 1930s with American companies that want to do business in Germany. That is mandatory technological transfers, usually for military purposes. But in a wider sense, whether you look at China or North Korea or the Iran deal, or the open borders with Mexico, what was going on was not a sustainable process and Trump he comes in as an outsider without military or prior political office and he looks at it in a different way and people get outraged. But he's brought -- he's brought more justice in 14 months in terms of trade with China than the previous three administrations.

DOBBS: Who actually did nothing but enable and cower before China and participate in the unprecedented transfer of wealth from this country to China and without perceptible benefit to the United States and anywhere.

HANSON: No. I think the premise that the more concessions that we gave China, we turn that magnanimity with reciprocal kindness whereas in fact, they have thought that it was a sign of weakness or that they are holding premise that would westernize them and they would be prosperous and they would join the family of nations and then democratize. It was flawed and they knew it was -- we were naive to believe it. And I think Trump doesn't believe it. He's cynical and he's right about that given human nature.

DOBBS: This President -- well, it's understandable that he would be cynical. He's assailed personally every day, attacked from every corner, even by members of his own party as he presses ahead. And he's accomplished more in the first not yet even 15 months of his presidency than his predecessors, most recent predecessors accomplished in any one of their terms and so it's striking. But at this point, the special counsel seems to have lost all direction is not following a moral compass nor a legal one. Your thoughts?

HANSON: Well, it's -- I hate to say this, but I think he's resembling Beria under Stalin that he said give the person and I'll find the crime. He starts with a premise that Donald Trump was a suspect, and whether it's collusion or obstruction of justice or now the Stormy Daniels matter, he's looking for a crime to fit the person. And each time he does this he erodes confidence in the quality and the quantity of the applicability of the law. So he wants to say that client-attorney relationship doesn't exist with Trump but it surely did with Cheryl Mills and Hillary Clinton when she sat in on FBI interviews and then said later that she could not be interviewed because she was Hillary Clinton's attorney. And the same thing with collusion. We know the Steele dossier was a prime example of collusion with the Russians. We know that if you're interested in obstruction of justice, the (INAUDIBLE) to go would have been the fraudulent circumstances under which those FISA requests were presented to FISA judges. And again and again, Mr. Mueller is ignoring a whole set of miscreants and that he's focusing on this obsession. He's sort of like Captain Ahab and the white whale. Trump is his whale and he can't let go.

DOBBS: Yes, I think there may be some greater purpose thought, here. It is -- he's got 13 of his 17 are Democrats and committed for most part, all of them committed ideologues. This looks like a continuation of the Obama administration's absolute assault on the Trump campaign to support Hillary Clinton. The insurance policy was the Russia collusion, contrivance and everybody knows it. And yet the Republican Party leadership hasn't got the guts to stand up and say, enough.

HANSON: Yes, well, I mean, it's even worse than that that there were attorneys on his team. Remember they were called the dream team, the A- team, all of these superlatives by the media but there were members of that team that are actually represented clients connected with Hillary Clinton's various scandal and that was not a conflict of interest. Four or five of them came from his own law firm, that was not a conflict, and they were mostly Democrats and many of them contributors. So if he wanted to project the appearance that he was not unbiased, he couldn't have done anything worse than what he did. It was almost as if he was attempting to show the nation that he was not going to be disinterested by the selections that he made.

DOBBS: There's -- no question that he is not concern about appearances at all. Let's -- we've got about a minute, Victor, your thoughts on the President's decision as he contemplates taking military action against Syria.

HANSON: Two quick things that -- he ran as a Jacksonian and he was going to be principled realismist to the doctrine so he's got to restore the terms that was lost under Obama and yet he cannot be a neo-conservative nation builder. He's in an ironic position that he wants to stop this if it exists, this use of chemical weapons. But the people who were going to be most suspect of intervening are the people who voted for him. And the people who will never vote for him are the people who egging him on to go in on a big way into Syria. So he's got to threat that needle politically and he's got to send a message to Putin. You cannot do this if he did it and yet we don't want another Afghanistan, so it's a tricky thing.

DOBBS: Victor Davis Hanson, good to see you. Thank you. Thanks for being with us tonight. That's it for us. Congressmen Matt Gaetz and Sean Duffy join us tomorrow.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X76-TX51-JB4M-V17K-00000-00Texas attorney general, Google's new competition cop, says everything is 'on the table';In an interview in his Austin office, Ken Paxton vows to get to the bottom of Google's business practices.2019-10-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:15ZLexisNexisTexas attorney general, Google's new competition cop, says everything is 'on the table'In an interview in his Austin office, Ken Paxton vows to get to the bottom of Google's business practices.Tony Romm

AUSTIN, Tex. - Ken Paxton is no fan of Google. The Lone Star state's Republican attorney general says he rarely even uses the company's widely popular search engine, opting instead for rival services, because he has "always been concerned about tracking."

But Paxton these days is more than a mere sideline skeptic: As one of the country's most powerful law-enforcement officials, he's forging ahead with a landmark investigation into Google's decades-long dominance of the web, armed with the help of 50 other attorneys general, a stable of savvy experts that includes Google's past foes, and a feeling that Washington for too long has turned a blind eye to some of Silicon Valley's most troubling practices.

For now, the investigation, which Paxton and his peers announced in September, focuses on online advertising, responding to complaints that Google puts consumers and competitors at a disadvantage by controlling the exchanges where ads are bought and some of the most popular websites where they're sold. It could result in tough punishments, Paxton signaled, if investigators determine Google broke the law.

"We're prepared for whatever the right thing to do is for consumers," he said during an interview with The Washington Post in his office in the Texas capital. Whether it's standing down or forcing Google to sell off parts of itself, Paxton stressed: "All of that's on the table based on what we learn."

The probe marks the first major U.S. antitrust action against Google in roughly a decade, after Texas joined other states and the federal government in scrutinizing the company's search engine in a competition probe that ended without major punishment for the tech giant.

Since then, Paxton said, Washington has failed to pursue key signs that Google and Silicon Valley are in violation of federal law. "Antitrust seems like it hasn't been focused on for decades, through several administrations, not just Democrats but also Republicans," he said, later adding: "I think this should have been looked at sooner than it is."

The result is a significant legal and political challenge on the horizon for Google and its executives. Bipartisan in nature, and born out of a belief that the tech industry has escaped government accountability for too long, Paxton and his team said nothing is off limits - words that threaten a broad review of Google's business in a way that could reshape not only the company but the rest of Silicon Valley.

"If we end up learning things that lead us in other directions, we'll certainly bring those back to the states and talk about whether we expand into other areas," he said.

Google declined to comment.

Overseeing an office with nearly 800 lawyers, Paxton emerged this year as a convening force in the sort of antitrust probe that's long been sought by Democratic and Republican attorneys general alike. Eight states, including Arizona, Nebraska and North Carolina, are helping to steer the Google probe as part of an executive committee, but it's Texas that started the legal action by sending a legal demand with hundreds of questions to Google on behalf of the group.

It is not the only probe of the tech giant under way: Investigators at the Department of Justice in Washington also are homing in on Google and its lucrative ad empire, and they sent their own battery of questions to the company this summer. Members of Congress similarly have targeted Google and other tech giants as part of a sweeping review of federal antitrust laws. And European regulators continue to scrutinize Google and its search, ad and smartphone practices, having already slapped it with roughly $9 billion in antitrust fines over the past three years.

For state attorneys general in the U.S., the driving question comes down to dollars, Paxton said. Ads targeted to people's browsing behavior are Google's lifeblood, accounting for much of the company's roughly $117 billion in revenue last year, according to its financial statements. That puts Google in the pole position in the United States, where it takes in around 37 percent of all digital advertising revenue, according to eMarketer data from February. In search, Google captures even more -- 74 percent -- of the market, the firm computes.

Importantly, ads provide financial fuel for Google's popular, free services, such as search, email and mapping, as well as its more audacious gambits, including self-driving cars. Paxton acknowledged these products are widely liked around the world, even if he personally doesn't use all of them regularly. But the attorney general stressed Google's dominance of the ad industry still has stifled the Internet.

"Consumers may feel really good about having free searches but the reality is nothing's free. And if there's no competition on the Internet for advertising, then consumers, unbeknownst to them, are paying much higher costs for products than they otherwise should," he said.

Google has sought to tell a different story about its business. Appearing on Capitol Hill in July, Adam Cohen, Google's director of economic policy, said that Internet advertising is cheaper and more effective than ever before. "We have created new competition in many sectors, and new competitive pressures often lead to concerns from rivals," he said in testimony. "We have consistently shown how our business is designed and operated to benefit our customers."

But Paxton said state investigators have heard from a torrent of competitors, particularly in the publishing industry, who say they cannot compete with Google's scale, meaning they lose out on revenue that might fund their content or services.

The vocal opponents include some of Google's long-time foes, such as News Corp., according to two Texas officials who requested anonymity to discuss private conversations in the probe. The Rupert Murdoch-backed empire previously has complained to antitrust regulators in Europe, Australia and elsewhere that Google's ad dominance results in fewer dollars for publishers, and News Corp. has gone as far as to call for the tech giant to be broken up at times.

A spokesman for News Corp., James Kennedy, declined to comment on the company's interactions with Texas. But, he added in a statement: "Our position regarding Google's damaging anti-competitive behavior and existential threat to journalism has been made clear over the years."

In probing those allegations, Paxton and his attorney general allies have turned to one of News Corp.'s past advisers. Among the experts the state has retained is Cristina Caffarra, who has assisted News Corp. and other Google foes on antitrust issues. A competition expert and economist at the consulting firm Charles River Associates, Caffarra boasts deep experience in Brussels, where Google has been repeatedly fined for competition violations. In those cases, including a recent decision finding Google's Android smartphone violated regional competition laws. Caffarra has supplied considerable economic evidence in opposition to Google's practices.

Caffarra also has worked on behalf of other Google foes, including the Russian search engine Yandex on its complaint in Moscow and the EU about Google's business practices, she's indicated in public reports. She declined to comment on her role in the states' probe, other than to say that she is not working for a corporate client that's opposing Google presently. But her participation in the states' effort took center stage in September, when she appeared alongside more than a dozen attorneys general when they announced their plans from the steps of the U.S. Supreme Court.

For Google, the states' probe could easily broaden beyond its ad business and its effects on publishers. Democratic and Republican attorneys general long have criticized the company for the way it collects users' data and displays its search results, for example, along with the means by which it has piloted Android to become the world's most widely used smartphone operating system. Some state officials raised these issues when they announced their ads probe in September.

Paxton's office has additional concerns of its own: Texas is in the early stages of a consumer-protection investigation focused on allegations that Google makes decisions about the content it displays and suppresses that are biased against conservatives. Jeff Mateer, Paxton's first assistant attorney general, confirmed the state's interest last week, four months after he aired his concerns at a conference in Omaha that big tech should be "held accountable" if the industry misrepresents its political neutrality. Google has denied charges that it is politically biased.

Texas long has long been troubled by Google's behavior. Roughly nine years ago, it became one of the first to embark on an antitrust investigation of Google when it opened a probe into the way the company presents search results. It was Paxton's predecessor, Greg Abbott, now the state's governor, who sought to determine if Google demoted competing services, such as shopping-comparison sites, that rivaled its own offerings, violating a principle that Texas called "search neutrality."

Texas issued some of the initial orders demanding key documents from Google, at one point going to court to battle the company over access to information. The answers the state obtained ultimately appeared to influence some of the thinking at the Federal Trade Commission, which assumed the role of Google's chief investigator in the United States. An inadvertently released staff report from that probe, which ended in 2013, cited emails, memos and other materials obtained by Texas in concluding Google had in fact put its rivals at a disadvantage.

In the end, though, the FTC opted against issuing steep penalties targeting the company's search practices, sparking widespread criticism that the federal government had failed to capitalize on the evidence trove that Texas helped amass.

Gary Reback, a lawyer at the firm Carr & Ferrell and a longtime Google foe, said the documents at the time showed that Google had "jimmied their normal algorithm to demote certain sites." It's hard to "generalize" from one investigation to another, he cautioned, "but what we do know is the Texas attorney general can be effective in getting the kind of information that might lead to government action."

But the timing of the states' latest investigation - and the optics of their announcement - still triggered criticism that the attorneys general hoped to leverage their work for political gain. The Competitive Enterprise Institute, a advocacy group that opposes antitrust law and has received contributions from Google, blasted the probe in September as an exercise that would "benefit state AGs' political ambitions, but impose harmful costs on consumers, businesses, and the economy."

Paxton, in particular, has issued at least two emails to supporters through his campaign, including an Oct. 2 note that said he needed $25 or more to "fight Google's dominance over so much of our lives," including the effects it has on publishers.

As such scrutiny intensifies, Paxton and his team cautioned they're at the beginning, not the end, of an investigation. With Google, in particular, "a lot of people just didn't understand the model" until recently, he said. "The way it's been done, it's been hard to get a grip on what's going on behind the scenes."

While he said that the broad, national participation reflects the seriousness of states' concerns, Paxton stressed they hadn't reached "any kind of conclusion, there's so much we don't know."

"Whatever that leads to," he added, "it leads to."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X7B-7WV1-F03R-N3FC-00000-00Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, Google's new competition cop, says everything is "on the table"2019-10-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:15ZLexisNexisTexas Attorney General Ken Paxton, Google's new competition cop, says everything is "on the table"Tony Romm, The Washington Post

Oct 08, 2019( The Texas Tribune: http://texastribune.org Delivered by Newstex) AUSTIN — Ken Paxton is no fan of Google. The Lone Star State's Republican attorney general says he rarely even uses the company's widely popular search engine, opting instead for rival services, because he has 'always been concerned about tracking.' But Paxton these days is more than a mere sideline skeptic: As one of the country's most powerful law-enforcement officials, he's forging ahead with a landmark investigation into Google's decades-long dominance of the web, armed with the help of 50 other attorneys general, a stable of savvy experts that includes Google's past foes, and a feeling that Washington for too long has turned a blind eye to some of Silicon Valley's most troubling practices. For now, the investigation, which Paxton and his peers announced in September[1], focuses on online advertising, responding to complaints that Google puts consumers and competitors at a disadvantage by controlling the exchanges where ads are bought and some of the most popular websites where they're sold.

It could result in tough punishments, Paxton signaled, if investigators determine Google broke the law. 'We're prepared for whatever the right thing to do is for consumers,' he said during an interview with The Washington Post in his office in the Texas capital. Whether it's standing down or forcing Google to sell off parts of itself, Paxton stressed: 'All of that's on the table based on what we learn.' The Texas Tribune thanks its sponsors. Become one[2].The probe marks the first major U.S. antitrust action against Google in roughly a decade, after Texas joined other states and the federal government in scrutinizing the company's search engine in a competition probe that ended without major punishment for the tech giant. Since then, Paxton said, Washington has failed to pursue key signs that Google and Silicon Valley are in violation of federal law. 'Antitrust seems like it hasn't been focused on for decades, through several administrations, not just Democrats but also Republicans,' he said, later adding: 'I think this should have been looked at sooner than it is.' The result is a significant legal and political challenge on the horizon for Google and its executives. Bipartisan in nature, and born out of a belief that the tech industry has escaped government accountability for too long, Paxton and his team said nothing is off limits — words that threaten a broad review of Google's business in a way that could reshape not only the company but the rest of Silicon Valley. 'If we end up learning things that lead us in other directions, we'll certainly bring those back to the states and talk about whether we expand into other areas,' he said.Google declined to comment. Overseeing an office with nearly 800 lawyers, Paxton emerged this year as a convening force in the sort of antitrust probe that's long been sought by Democratic and Republican attorneys general alike[3]. Eight states, including Arizona, Nebraska and North Carolina, are helping to steer the Google probe as part of an executive committee, but it's Texas that started the legal action by sending a legal demand with hundreds of questions to Google on behalf of the group. It is not the only probe of the tech giant under way: Investigators at the Department of Justice[4] in Washington also are homing in on Google and its lucrative ad empire, and they sent their own battery of questions[5] to the company this summer. Members of Congress similarly have targeted Google and other tech giants as part of a sweeping review of federal antitrust laws[6]. And European regulators continue to scrutinize Google and its search, ad and smartphone practices, having already slapped it [7]with roughly $9 billion in antitrust fines over the past three years. For state attorneys general in the U.S., the driving question comes down to dollars, Paxton said. Ads targeted to people's browsing behavior are Google's lifeblood, accounting for much of the company's roughly $117 billion in revenue last year, according to its financial statements. That puts Google in the pole position in the United States, where it takes in around 37 percent of all digital advertising revenue, according to eMarketer data from February. In search, Google captures even more -- 74 percent -- of the market, the firm computes. The Texas Tribune thanks its sponsors. Become one[8].Importantly, ads provide financial fuel for Google's popular, free services, such as search, email and mapping, as well as its more audacious gambits, including self-driving cars. Paxton acknowledged these products are widely liked around the world, even if he personally doesn't use all of them regularly. But the attorney general stressed Google's dominance of the ad industry still has stifled the Internet. "Consumers may feel really good about having free searches but the reality is nothing's free. And if there's no competition on the Internet for advertising, then consumers, unbeknownst to them, are paying much higher costs for products than they otherwise should,' he said. Google has sought to tell a different story about its business. Appearing on Capitol Hill in July, Adam Cohen, Google's director of economic policy, said that Internet advertising is cheaper and more effective than ever before. 'We have created new competition in many sectors, and new competitive pressures often lead to concerns from rivals,' he said in testimony[9]. 'We have consistently shown how our business is designed and operated to benefit our customers.' But Paxton said state investigators have heard from a torrent of competitors, particularly in the publishing industry, who say they cannot compete with Google's scale, meaning they lose out on revenue that might fund their content or services. The Texas Tribune thanks its sponsors. Become one[10].The vocal opponents include some of Google's long-time foes, such as News Corp., according to two Texas officials who requested anonymity to discuss private conversations in the probe. The Rupert Murdoch-backed empire previously has complained to antitrust regulators in Europe, Australia and elsewhere that Google's ad dominance results in fewer dollars for publishers, and News Corp. has gone as far as to call for the tech giant to be broken up at times. A spokesman for News Corp., James Kennedy, declined to comment on the company's interactions with Texas. But, he added in a statement: 'Our position regarding Google's damaging anti-competitive behavior and existential threat to journalism has been made clear over the years.' In probing those allegations, Paxton and his attorney general allies have turned to one of News Corp.'s past advisers. Among the experts the state has retained is Cristina Caffarra, who has assisted News Corp. and other Google foes on antitrust issues. A competition expert and economist at the consulting firm Charles River Associates, Caffarra boasts deep experience in Brussels, where Google has been repeatedly fined for competition violations. In those cases, including a recent decision finding Google's Android smartphone violated regional competition laws. Caffarra has supplied considerable economic evidence in opposition to Google's practices. Caffarra also has worked on behalf of other Google foes, including the Russian search engine Yandex on its complaint in Moscow and the EU about Google's business practices, she's indicated in public reports. She declined to comment on her role in the states' probe, other than to say that she is not working for a corporate client that's opposing Google presently. But her participation in the states' effort took center stage in September, when she appeared alongside more than a dozen attorneys general when they announced their plans from the steps of the U.S. Supreme Court. The Texas Tribune thanks its sponsors. Become one[11].For Google, the states' probe could easily broaden beyond its ad business and its effects on publishers. Democratic and Republican attorneys general long have criticized the company for the way it collects users' data[12] and displays its search results, for example, along with the means by which it has piloted Android to become the world's most widely used smartphone operating system. Some state officials raised these issues when they announced their ads probe in September[13]. Paxton's office has additional concerns of its own: Texas is in the early stages of a consumer-protection investigation focused on allegations that Google makes decisions about the content it displays and suppresses that are biased against conservatives. Jeff Mateer, Paxton's first assistant attorney general, confirmed the state's interest last week, four months after he aired his concerns at a conference in Omaha that big tech should be 'held accountable'[14] if the industry misrepresents its political neutrality. Google has denied charges that it is politically biased. Texas long has long been troubled by Google's behavior. Roughly nine years ago[15], it became one of the first to embark on an antitrust investigation of Google when it opened a probe into the way the company presents search results. It was Paxton's predecessor, Greg Abbott, now the state's governor, who sought to determine if Google demoted competing services, such as shopping-comparison sites, that rivaled its own offerings, violating a principle that Texas called 'search neutrality.' Texas issued some of the initial orders demanding key documents from Google, at one point going to court to battle the company over access to information. The answers the state obtained ultimately appeared to influence some of the thinking at the Federal Trade Commission, which assumed the role of Google's chief investigator in the United States. An inadvertently released staff report[16] from that probe, which ended in 2013, cited emails, memos and other materials obtained by Texas in concluding Google had in fact put its rivals at a disadvantage. The Texas Tribune thanks its sponsors. Become one[17].In the end, though, the FTC opted against issuing steep penalties targeting the company's search practices, sparking widespread criticism that the federal government had failed to capitalize on the evidence trove that Texas helped amass. Gary Reback, a lawyer at the firm Carr ...rrell and a longtime Google foe, said the documents at the time showed that Google had 'jimmied their normal algorithm to demote certain sites." It's hard to 'generalize' from one investigation to another, he cautioned, 'but what we do know is the Texas attorney general can be effective in getting the kind of information that might lead to government action.' But the timing of the states' latest investigation — and the optics of their announcement — still triggered criticism that the attorneys general hoped to leverage their work for political gain. The Competitive Enterprise Institute, a advocacy group that opposes antitrust law[18] and has received contributions from Google[19], blasted the probe in September as an exercise that would 'benefit state AGs' political ambitions, but impose harmful costs on consumers, businesses, and the economy.' Paxton, in particular, has issued at least two emails to supporters through his campaign, including an Oct. 2 note[20] that said he needed $25 or more to 'fight Google's dominance over so much of our lives,' including the effects it has on publishers.The Texas Tribune thanks its sponsors. Become one[21].As such scrutiny intensifies, Paxton and his team cautioned they're at the beginning, not the end, of an investigation. With Google, in particular, 'a lot of people just didn't understand the model' until recently, he said. 'The way it's been done, it's been hard to get a grip on what's going on behind the scenes.' While he said that the broad, national participation reflects the seriousness of states' concerns, Paxton stressed they hadn't reached 'any kind of conclusion, there's so much we don't know.' 'Whatever that leads to,' he added, 'it leads to.' Disclosure: Google has been a financial supporter of of The Texas Tribune, a nonprofit, nonpartisan news organization that is funded in part by donations from members, foundations and corporate sponsors. Financial supporters play no role in the Tribune's journalism. Find a complete list of them here[22].Read related Tribune coverageQuality journalism doesn't come freePerhaps it goes without saying — but producing quality journalism isn't cheap. At a time when newsroom resources and revenue across the country are declining, The Texas Tribune remains committed to sustaining our mission[23]: creating a more engaged and informed Texas with every story we cover, every event we convene and every newsletter we send. As a nonprofit newsroom, we rely on members to help keep our stories free and our events open to the public. Do you value our journalism? Show us with your support.Yes, I'll donate today[24] [ 1]:
