Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60GR-C121-F07F-84BB-00000-00The 5 technologies set to drive more agile, scalable advertising capabilities for marketers2020-08-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:15ZLexisNexisNEWSThe 5 technologies set to drive more agile, scalable advertising capabilities for marketers

Among the 19 technologies represented in the Gartner Hype Cycle for Digital Advertising 2020 report, marketers should keep an eye on advanced supply-side bidding, ad blocking, identity resolution, brand safety, and ad verification and viewability in partic... Among the 19 technologies represented in the Gartner Hype Cycle for Digital Advertising 2020 report, marketers should keep an eye...

Among the 19 technologies represented in the Gartner Hype Cycle for Digital Advertising 2020 report, marketers should keep an eye on advanced supply-side bidding, ad blocking, identity resolution, brand safety, and ad verification and viewability in partic...

Among the 19 technologies represented in the Gartner Hype Cycle for Digital Advertising 2020 report, marketers should keep an eye on advanced supply-side bidding, ad blocking, identity resolution, brand safety, and ad verification and viewability in particular. “Significant changes to the marketplace, such as cookie obsolescence and dominance by Facebook and Google, combined with a rising level of consumer mistrust in ‘big tech’ have created a tipping point for digital advertising,” said Colin Reid , senior director analyst at Gartner for Marketers . “These changes in the ad tech market will cause some existing digital advertising sectors and established supply chains to wither and vanish.” Increased regulatory scrutiny, continued media supply chain disruption and volatile consumer spending are three emerging trends that will have the greatest impact on marketers’ ability to implement effective and scalable advertising capabilities. Hype Cycle for Digital Advertising, 2020 Source: Gartner (July 2020) Advanced Supply-Side Bidding (ASSB) Demand for ASSB – techniques that allow publishers to solicit bids from multiple sources to fill an available ad spot – is a clear signal that removing barriers to open competition in media markets can yield major economic benefits for buyers and sellers. Marketers should expect continued innovation and pressure to be directed at similar attempts to level the playing field by addressing impediments to a less concentrated market. However, the impact of regulatory developments on ASSB remains unpredictable, especially in regard to curtailing of trade in targeting data for advertising. As programmatic ad markets take the brunt of a pandemic-induced recession’s impact on media budgets, it will likely take ASSB at least three more years to reach the Plateau of Productivity. Ad Blocking Over the last few years, ad blocking – the use of software to remove or filter the delivery of content identified as advertising from material published on the internet – has gained significant traction. However, attention and hysteria surrounding ad blocking have been recently eclipsed by concerns about the demise of third-party cookies and the chilling impact of COVID-19 on the digital ad market. Underlying issues with ad blocking are still very much unresolved and unlikely to stabilize within the next two years. In the meantime, marketers must look to better balance customer choice and engagement with increasing demands for transparency. Identity Resolution (IDR) IDR holds great promise for marketers as they shift their sights to customer retention goals, do more with a stagnant or cut budget and apply first-party data to marketing programs. However, the technology is among the most active battlegrounds in a volatile power struggle between business interests, privacy regulators, and the largest digital platform providers – with consumers caught somewhere in the middle. Privacy obstacles put tremendous pressure on IDR practices, leading to its position on this year’s Hype Cycle – the Trough of Disillusionment. The future of IDR depends heavily on standardization – or supporting a universal user token compliant with consent requirements – which has been a rocky road. Marketers that altogether abandon efforts at using IDR to understand and communicate with customers, and those that rely on weak enforcement or sketchy privacy workarounds to obtain personal data, all risk negative impact. Brand Safety Brand safety has a renewed focus as of late, as marketers pay more attention to the context in which their ads appear . Previously included in the profile for ad verification, brand safety has been separated based on its unique requirements and trajectory, as it is measured and managed separately from fraud and viewability. As publishers evolve their ability to filter content, marketers will have a more reliable and direct way to manage their ad buys. However, as influencer marketing gains more investments, marketers will need to more closely scrutinize the process of influencer selection and look to technology to provide an efficient and reliable way to manage campaigns. Ad Verification and Viewability Ad verification and viewability – a fraud-prevention technology that verifies humans, not bots are the source of impressions and clicks – has emerged from the Trough of Disillusionment into the Slope of Enlightenment due to the recent trend of provider acquisitions by strategic buyers. Marketers investing in digital advertising have a great deal to lose from ad fraud and viewability violations. Verification will be a necessary part of the settlement systems of buyers and sellers as the category moves toward maturity. Marketers will need to institute an approach to ad verification and viewability to ensure they can take full advantage of it and have confidence in the investment. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T7J-XSV1-JCG7-V42S-00000-00The 8 Most Revealing Quotes from the Big Zuckerberg Profile2018-09-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:15ZLexisNexisThe 8 Most Revealing Quotes from the Big Zuckerberg ProfileAlexis C. Madrigal


Mark Zuckerberg is impossible to profile. He's a narrative anti-catalyst, who takes all the elements of a fantastic story, and renders them lifeless, probably on purpose. The latest New Yorker contains about 14,000 exceedingly well-crafted words about Zuckerberg, and yet, not once do we catch a glimpse the man outside his carefully managed cocoon of self-awareness. When there is a reporter around, he's never thinking aloud, or hanging around with his friends, or talking shit. He is never in the heat of the moment. He is the anti-Elon Musk.


But Zuckerberg says what he means to say. If you go back through Facebook's history, Zuckerberg has telegraphed what his company will do. With that in mind, here are eight things that Zuckerberg said that are worth paying attention to, beginning with his argument against regulation.
1. Why shouldn't Congress regulate big-tech companies?
In the past,   Facebook executives have warned, with straight faces, that more onerous regulation would hurt smaller internet companies, further entrenching the company's own power. But in the New Yorker profile, Zuckerberg gave a different justification for the government to keep its hands off: American global competitiveness, and the specter of an internet dominated by Chinese companies.
  Zuckerberg 2020?
"I think that anything that we're doing to constrain [big-tech companies] will, first, have an impact on how successful we can be in other places," he said. "I wouldn't worry in the near term about Chinese companies or anyone else winning in the U.S., for the most part. But there are all these places where there are day-to-day more competitive situations-in Southeast Asia, across Europe, Latin America, lots of different places."
2. Why has the company been so passive about ethnic cleansing in Myanmar?
The   brutal treatment of the Rohingya people has garnered coverage around the world, with many   humanitarian observers   pointing their fingers at Facebook's role in whipping up divisive fervor. Yet the company struggled to even face the problem   for years. Zuckerberg offered the promise that the company knows it has problems there.
"We're taking this seriously," he said. "You can't just snap your fingers and solve these problems. It takes time to hire the people and train them, and to build the systems that can flag stuff for them."
He also said that he "hates" that Facebook is "not moving as quickly as would like."
3. Why is Mark Zuckerberg obsessed with Augustus, the Roman emperor?
In perhaps the most fascinating section of the profile, Zuckerberg described his interest in Augustus, who, by his description, "through a really harsh approach, he established two hundred years of world peace."
His interest is longstanding. "My wife was making fun of me, saying she thought there were three people on the honeymoon: me, her, and Augustus," Zuckerberg said of a 2012 trip to Rome. "All the photos were different sculptures of Augustus."
  The 13 strangest moments from the Zuckerberg hearing
Osnos suggests that Zuckerberg is interested in the way the Roman leaders had to deal with very tough "trade-offs," as Zuckerberg put it. Ancient Rome had "good and bad and complex figures" who were working out issues of power and the common good. What should one be willing to do to bring 200 years of world peace? Mark Zuckerberg has clearly considered this particular scale of justice.
4. Is "fake news" an overblown problem?
Here, we're talking about the original definition of "fake news," which is hoax stories created whole-cloth from nothing. Many analyses found that these stories were very popular in the run up to the 2016 election, but were also a small percentage of the overall Facebook conversation around the election.
Given the definition, Zuckerberg continues to think this kind of "fake news" is overblown. "The average person might perceive, from how much we and others talk about it, that there is more than ten times as much misinformation or hoax content on Facebook than the academic measures that we've seen so far suggest," he said.
  Did these hoaxes have an effect on the 2016 election? "I still think that's the kind of thing that needs to be studied," he told Osnos.
5. Will one social network rule them all?
The world is increasingly socially networked. Nonetheless, Zuckerberg tells the New Yorker "there's a natural zero-sumness" to these competing platforms. Facebook can't just build the "best features," but has to build "the best community."
It would be interesting to know how Zuckerberg reconciles this belief with the fact that Facebook operates three different huge social networks-the core service, Instagram, and WhatsApp. Can there be multiple best communities?
6. Does Zuckerberg read a traditional newspaper?
"There's really no newspaper that I pick up and read front to back," he said. "Well, that might be true of most people these days-most people don't read the physical paper-but there aren't many news Web sites where I go to browse."
7. Can technologists and doctors end disease?
Zuckerberg talks briefly about the ambitions he has for the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative, the expansive,   mostly philanthropic effort he's committed 99 percent of his family's wealth to. One stated aspiration is to "help cure all disease in our children's lifetime," but does Zuckerberg really think that's possible?
"On average, every year for the last 80 years or so, I think, life expectancy has gone up by about a quarter of a year. And, if you believe that technological and scientific progress is not going to slow, there is a potential upside to speeding that up," he said. "We're going to get to a point where the life expectancy implied by extrapolating that out will mean that we'll basically have been able to manage or cure all of the major things that people suffer from and die from today. Based on the data that we already see, it seems like there's a reasonable shot."
So, yes, he does believe there is a "reasonable shot" at helping cure all diseases in the next, say, 100 years.
8. Does Mark Zuckerberg have emotions?
I asked Zuckerberg whether he finds it insulting when people speculate that he lacks emotions. "Insulting?" he asked, and then paused for several seconds to consider. "I don't find it insulting. I don't think it's accurate. I mean, I definitely care a lot. There's a difference between letting emotions drive impulsive decisions and caring." He went on, "Ultimately, I think the reason that we built this successful thing is because we just solve problem after problem after problem, and typically you don't do that by making impulsive, emotional decisions."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5R5M-DDR1-F03R-N041-00000-00The 10 Most Exciting Digital Health Stories of 20172017-12-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:15ZLexisNexisThe 10 Most Exciting Digital Health Stories of 2017nora

Dec 13, 2017( ScienceRoll: http://scienceroll.com Delivered by Newstex) Gene-edited human embryo. Self-driving trucks. Practical quantum computers. 2017 has been an exciting year for science, technology - and digital health! It's that time of the year again when it's worth looking back at the past months; and list the inventions, methods and milestone events in healthcare to get a clearer picture what will shape medicine for the years to come.2017 - Amazing year for science and healthcareScientists, researchers, and innovators come up with amazing breakthroughs every year, and that was no different in 2017 either.

No matter whether we look at physics (proving the existence of gravitational waves[1]), astronomy (discovering new planets[2]) or biology (detecting a fluorescent frog in Brazil[3]), we come across mind-blowing scientific findings everywhere. Healthcare was no exception, moreover, some say the field of medicine is one of the most innovative fields today. Looking back at our expectations in digital health for 2017[4] in terms of trends, innovations or breakthroughs, there were at least three developments and three trends, which proved to be foresightful. The beginning of a new era in diabetes care is upon us with the realities of the FDA-approved artificial pancreas[5] or such small, but significant innovations as a glucose monitor built into phone cases[6]. Artificial narrow intelligence (ANI), mainly computer vision and natural language processing, started to take its place in healthcare - in spite of such bumps on the road until widespread use as overhyping the technology[7]. Precision medicine is incrementally reshaping cancer care methods: DNA-tests from tumors and patients are used to work out targeted treatments in the fight against cancer. Moreover, I predicted that a health insurance company will launch a package which will include fitness trackers and wearables; that a big tech company will step up its efforts in digital health; and further steps will be made in the development of the CRISPR genome-editing method. Although we still have to wait for the first clinical trials, New Scientist has already reported in April 2017 that there are as many as 20 human trials underway, mostly in China. But I rushed ahead of myself. Let's dive into the details step by step! If you prefer videos, here are the top 5 stories described in less than 3 minutes: Play Video[8] 1) Canada started to embrace digital health[9]New technological solutions and breakthrough methods produced by the market cannot be fruitful without the appropriate regulations ensuring the safety, the rights and the freedom to innovate for every player. The Canadian government recognized the current challenges in their healthcare system and decided to take action. The Standing Senate Committee on Social Affairs, Science and Technology invited researchers, ethicists, entrepreneurs, and futurists like me to discuss the way forward. In October 2017, they published a report entitled Challenge Ahead: Integrating Robotics, Artificial Intelligence, and 3D Printing Technologies into Canada's Healthcare Systems[10] with actionable recommendations for the future. The Senate Committee realized the transformative power of 3D printing, A.I., and robotics, while it also seems to be willing to tackle ethical concerns, legal issues around these new technologies and their consequences on the labor market. The group recommended the government to host a Forum for Health Discovery so entrepreneurs and innovators could present their latest healthcare related work; to convene a National Conference on Robotics, A.I. and 3D Printing in Healthcare and establish various working groups to deal with technological, ethical and regulatory concerns of innovations in the industry. I believe this is the way for every responsible government to bring its healthcare system into the 21st century. 2) Insurance companies integrated fitness wearables into their programsLast year, I predicted that the accumulation of personal data stemming from wearables will lead a huge insurance company to launch a package containing wearable sensors and guidance about living a healthy life by measuring data. In November, Qualcomm and United Healthcare announced[11] that they have integrated Samsung and Garmin wearables into their national wellness program. It enables eligible plan participants to earn more than $1,000 per year by meeting daily walking goals. As according to estimations[12] 245 million wearable devices will be sold in 2019, more and more accurate data sets about our lifestyle through trackers and wearables become available. It is inevitable insurance companies will try to utilize them. I believe that in the future, smoking, drinking heavily, eating trashy food and not doing any sports might not only cost people a lot in terms of their expenses and their health on the long run, but it might also heavily burden their health insurance - e.g. through not being able to access certain privileges. 3) Artificial Intelligence ...diologyAs briefly mentioned above, the two most radically improving subfields of ANI, computer vision, and natural language processing, are taking their place in healthcare. Researchers achieved amazing results with computer vision in the field of medical imaging. Scientists at the University of Adelaide have been experimenting with an AI system that is said to be able to tell if you are going to die[13]. But that's just the tip of the iceberg. From IBM Watson through Philips, Agfa, Siemens until GE, giant healthcare players have already started integrating AI into their medical imaging software systems. Moreover, the FDA approved the first cloud-based deep learning algorithm for cardiac imaging developed by Arterys in 2017[14]. It is a giant leap towards integrating A.I. into radiology which might become part of radiologists' daily routine sooner than you think. Anna Fernandez, Health Informatics/Precision Medicine Lead at Booz Allen Hamilton told me that within 3 years we'll have many machine learning algorithms in active clinical pilot testing and in approved use. It will help diagnose simpler cases and take over repetitive tasks. However, I'm sure that radiologists' creative work will be necessary in the future to solve complex issues and supervising diagnostic processes. A.I. will not replace radiologists, but make them better! 4) The FDA approved the first 'digital pill'The amazing advancement of nanotechnology is making the production of 'digestibles[15]' as a potential way for drug making possible. These tiny pills or gadgets combined with a sensor could track digestion and the absorption of drugs after swallowing them. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration, the FDA, granted a green light for the first pill with a digital ingestion tracking system in 2017[16]. The drug called Abilify MyCite was developed by the Japanese Otsuka Pharmaceutical, augmented by an accompanying wearable patch produced by Proteus Digital Health. With the patient's approval, the ingestible sensor communicates with the wearable sensor patch if the drug is taken; then the information is transmitted to a smartphone or tablet of the caretaker or the patient himself. The ultimate aim is to measure drug adherence in the treatment of adults with schizophrenia, acute treatment of manic and mixed episodes associated with bipolar I disorder, and as adjunctive therapy for the treatment of major depressive disorders in adults. 5) Medical chatbots and health assistants on the riseChatbots, A.I. supported messaging apps or voice controlled bots[17] are forecasted to replace simple messaging apps soon. In healthcare, they could help solve easily diagnosable health concerns or support patient management, e.g. general organizational issues. In the last months, several signs have pointed to the direction that a more widespread use is forthcoming. Ada Health[18] has been the fastest growing medical app in Europe in 2017. Over 1.5 million people already tried the health companion app, which is able to assess the user's health based on the indicated symptoms using its vast, A.I.-based database. The UK's National Health Service (NHS) started to use[19] a chatbot[20] app for dispensing medical advice for a trial period in 2017, with the aim of reducing the burden on its 111 non-emergency helplines. The NHS is developing the app with Babylon Health[21], one of the new breed of paid, doctor-on-demand services[22]. Although the initial results how patients utilize the new resource show somewhat mixed achievements[23], I believe, this is the way to go in the future. 6) Medical VR for pain managementVirtual reality has been marching triumphantly into healthcare. In the past months, it turned out that it can offer an out-of-the-box solution for managing chronic pain and an effective prevention of the use of prescription opioids. Brennan Spiegel and his team at the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center are experimenting with the technology and they found a significant drop in pain scores in case of VR therapies[24]. Josh Sackman, President of applied VR[25], a Los Angeles-based company offering patients a non-drug escape route out of pain or panic through virtual reality, told The Medical Futurist, that VR can help increase access to a low cost, yet effective pain management resource. He added, that in the US, there are currently 100 million sufferers of chronic pain; and VR offers an effective alternative for opioid painkillers supporting the fight against the recent opioid crisis[26]. Play Video[27] 7) Roche acquired mySugrAustrian diabetes management start-up, mySugr[28] has been specializing in app-based, all-around care for people with diabetes since 2012. Pioneer in gamification and creator of the diabetes monster, mySugr has already over a million registered users, is available in 52 countries and in 13 different languages. The successful venture was acquired by the global pharmaceutical company, Roche[29] during the summer. While the start-up itself remained a separate legal entity, its app became an integral part of Roche's new patient-centered digital health services platform in diabetes care. The acquisition made it possible for users to connect their mySugr app with Roche's Accu-Chek tools, such as the Accu-Chek Guide glucose meter. The deal is important as it shows that huge pharma companies started to understand the value of health tech start-ups' solutions and unique expertise. So, instead of trying to come up with their products and services on their own, they rather team up with market players coming up with niche, value-based results. I believe we'll see more similar arrangements in the future. 8) Microsoft launched a new healthcare divisionLast December, I predicted that the race among tech giants will not tone down when it comes to healthcare. Although Google, Apple, Microsoft, IBM, they all showed interest in medicine they should and they will step up their efforts[30]. Google has made steps forward in healthcare with Calico[31]. Human Longevity Inc.[32] joined forces with Cleveland Clinic for a human genomics collaboration aimed at disease discovery and making aging a chronic condition. IBM has been developing its artificial intelligence program, Watson, and puts it to use in cardiology and cancer care. For this year, I expected another tech giant making extra efforts in improving research in healthcare. In September 2017, Microsoft announced the launch of its new healthcare division[33] at its Cambridge research facility, as part of plans to use its artificial intelligence software to enter the health market. Its research plans include monitoring systems that can help keep patients out of hospitals, and large studies into conditions such as diabetes. 9) CRISPR and the first gene-edited embryosThe amazing genome editing method, CRISPR has the potential to transform medicine as we know it. Although its research is in its infancy, studies and clinical probes show the method's rapid development and incredible power. While in 2016, experiments showed how[34] scientists were able to treat mice with Duchenne's muscular dystrophy through gene editing, a year later the MIT Technology Review reported[35] about the first known attempt at creating genetically modified human embryos in the United States. I predicted that in 2017, we would have a great chance for launching the first clinical trials to test the real power of CRISPR in changing devastating diseases. It's happening. As I mentioned before, in May, New Scientist reported that as many as 20 human trials will be underway soon[36], mostly in China. A few months later, in October, Nature reported that Chinese researchers created cloned embryos with a genetic mutation[37] for a potentially fatal blood disorder; then precisely corrected the DNA through 'base editing', a modification of the CRISPR/Cas-9 to show how to potentially prevent the condition at the earliest stages of development. These stories will keep multiplying in the future and we have to pay a lot more attention to the ethical consequences! 10) The FDA about the future of 3D PrintingOn 4 December 2017, the FDA Commissioner Dr. Scott Gottlieb released a statement[38] reaffirming the agency's commitment to a 'new era of 3D printing of medical products[39].' The statement outlines that the regulatory institution has reviewed over a hundred 3D printed medical devices currently on the market: from spinal implants[40] and custom facial reconstructions to 3D printed pills - the first of which was given a green light by the FDA in 2015.[41] The FDA's document shows its confidence about the further spread of 3D printing in medicine and healthcare, and it also demonstrates its preparation for the coming developments in synthetic organ production and biomedical additive manufacturing. As for example, Organovo's first bioprinted products are expected to make it to the FDA in 201[42]9, we'll definitely hear a lot of regulatory discussions about 3D printing in 2018.2017 has indeed been an incredibly exciting year. We can't wait for all the amazing innovations coming our way next year. But whatever happens, The Medical Futurist team will be here and all over our social media channels to cover exciting news and provide the necessary context in order to step into the future well-informed and confident. Subscribe to The Medical Futurist℠ NewsletterNews shaping the future of healthcare Advice on taking charge of your health Reviews of the latest health technology The post The 10 Most Exciting Digital Health Stories of 2017[43] appeared first on The Medical Futurist[44]. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60G8-HYR1-DXH2-6001-00000-00The 11th Hour With Brian Williams for July 29, 20202020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:15ZLexisNexis11TH HOUR WITH BRIAN WILLIAMS11:00 PM ESTIrwin Redlener, David Cicilline, David Plouffe, Scott Galloway, Tom CostelloNEWSDomestic072901cb.473The 11th Hour With Brian Williams for July 29, 2020Brian Williams, Shannon Pettypiece, Jeremy Bash

Dr. Anthony Fauci said that trials have shown "consistently" that hydroxychloroquine is "not effective" in treating the disease caused by the coronavirus. Fauci`s comments came as President Donald Trump faces questions over his promotion of a now-deleted video in which a doctor claimed that the drug was a "cure" for COVID-19. Representative Louie Gohmert who has refused to wear a mask, tested positive for the coronavirus Wednesday shortly before he was expected to travel with President Donald Trump to Texas. Trump attacks "radical Democrats" claims they don`t love our country. Trump tells suburban voters they will "no longer be bothered" by low-income housing. GOP grills tech execs about anti-conservative bias. Mars 2020 rover launch is NASA`s latest attempt to look for ancient life.

LAWRENCE O`DONNELL, MSNBC HOST: That is tonight`s LAST WORD. "THE 11TH HOUR" with Brian Williams starts now.

BRIAN WILLIAMS, MSNBC HOST: And good evening once again. Day 1,287 of the Trump administration, leaving exactly 97 days to go until the Presidential Election.

The President was in Texas today campaigning before a largely unmasked crowd in the midst of a terrible spike in illness there locally, trying to project the picture of strength as the coronavirus ravages that state. His visit came as Texas set a new single day death toll of 313. Trump didn`t mention that nor the thousands of Texans now infected with the virus. Here is some of what he did say.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, (R) UNITED STATES PRESIDENT: It`s not just Texas oil, that the radical Democrats want to destroy, they want to destroy our country. These people are sick, there`s no respect but there is by you. And there is by 95% of our people. Our people love our country. And our people love our anthem and they love our flag. They don`t love our country in any way, shape or form.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: There are now over 4.4 million confirmed cases in our country and our national death toll has climbed past 151,000. Think of it this way the first death was five months ago today. Five months later, over 151,000 dead. Over 1300 people have died in just the past 24 hours.

California and Florida also reporting record numbers of fatalities and now Florida is facing a possible Tropical Storm running right up the middle of the state, which is already shutting down testing centers for the next several days.

Two key reports out today make it clear the nation is not winning this fight one from Johns Hopkins says "the United States is not currently on course to get control of this epidemic." If that doesn`t get your attention, this will, from the Association of American Medical Colleges, "If the nation does not change its course and soon, deaths in the United States could be well into the multiple hundreds of thousands."

Yet the President today was repeating his defense of Dr. Stella Immanuel, the Houston based physician and minister who has spoken of in no particular order, alien DNA, demon sperm and spontaneous pregnancies. She`s the one on that video talking about a cure for coronavirus saying, no one`s needs masks and talk up the malaria drug that the President once again is promoting.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I was very impressed with her and other doctors that stood with her. I know nothing about, I just saw her, you know, making a statement with very respected doctors. She was making a statement about hydroxychloroquine with other doctors that swear by it, they think it`s great.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: Earlier on this network, Dr. Anthony Fauci was adamant as he tried to set the record straight.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DR. ANTHONY FAUCI, DIRECTOR OF THE NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES: The scientific data, the cumulative data on trials, clinical trials that were valid, namely clinical trials that were randomized and controlled in the proper way. All of those trials show consistently that hydroxychloroquine is not effective in the treatment of coronavirus disease, or COVID-19.

We`ve got to follow the science and when there`s a video out there for a bunch of people spouting something that isn`t true. The only recourse you have is to be very, very clear in presenting the scientific data that essentially contradicts that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: Most medical experts agree that right now masks are the frontline defense against the virus. Also the simplest thing we can do. Today Republican Congressman Louie Gohmert of Texas tested positive. He`s been an ardent mask denier who just recently started wearing one. He apparently learned about his results this morning as he was about to board Air Force One for the trip to Texas with the President. In a statement, the Congressman offered his theory about his infection.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REPRESENTATIVE LOUIE GOHMERT, (R) TEXAS: I can`t help but wonder if by keeping your mask on and keeping it in place that if I might have put some germs and wire some of the virus onto the mask and breathed it in, I don`t know. But I got it. We`ll see happens from here.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: If you miss the nuance there Gohmert is apparently blaming his mask wearing for the coronavirus. He`s on the House Judiciary Committee took part in yesterday`s hearing with the Attorney General. The two we`re seeing talking outside of the hearing room neither with a mask. Barr was tested today, his results were negative.

Speaker Pelosi has now mandated masks be worn on the floor of the House of Representatives. Coupled with concern over Trump`s response to the health crisis here within the U.S. there is growing alarm over his handling of a key global rival. In a portion of an interview with Axios, the President said during his recent call with Vladimir Putin, he never raised those reports of Russian bounties on the heads of our servicemen and women in Afghanistan.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You had a phone call with Vladimir Putin on July 23. Did you bring up this issue?

TRUMP: No, that was a phone call to discuss other things and frankly that`s an issue that many people said was fake news. If you look at some of the wonderful folks from the Bush administration, some of them not any friends of mine were saying that it`s a fake issue. But a lot of people said it`s a fake issue.

We had a call talking about nuclear proliferation, which is a very big subject where they would like to do something and so when I. We discussed numerous things. We did not discuss that, no.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: And you`ve never discussed it with it him?

TRUMP: I have never discussed it with him, no. I would, I have no problem with it.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Since you don`t believe the intelligence, that`s why?

TRUMP: Everything, you know, it`s interesting, nobody ever brings up China though, is bring Russia, Russia, Russia. They didn`t think it was real. They didn`t think it was worthy. I wouldn`t mind if it reached my desk, I would have done something about it. It never reached my desk because --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Do you read your recent brief?

TRUMP: I do. I read a lot. I comprehend extraordinarily well, probably better than anybody that you`ve interviewed in a long time. I read a lot.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: This morning at the White House, Trump claimed Colin Powell was the Bush administration figure who called it a fake issue. That was not the case. In fact, on this network Powell only spoke about media coverage of the report. Trump also added this about the reports of Russian bounties.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I don`t know why they`d be doing it, but if you tell me they`re doing it, I will certainly take that under consideration.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: How would you respond if Russia did turn out to have done that? How would you respond if --

TRUMP: I would respond appropriately. Nobody has been tougher on Russia.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: On another front today, the administration confirmed it intends to withdraw almost 12,000 of our troops from Germany, something a lot of people believe has been at or near the top of Vladimir Putin`s wish list for years. Those militarized federal agents in this country cracking down on protests in Portland may also be on the move the governor of Oregon says federal authorities have agreed to withdraw the forces tomorrow afternoon. But the Department of Homeland Security says the feds are staying there for now.

Also tonight, Atlanta, the city that became the center of nonviolent resistance during the civil rights struggle is paying final tribute to the late Congressman John Lewis. His funeral will take place there tomorrow. Barack Obama will deliver the eulogy, former presidents Clinton and Bush will also reportedly attend.

One more late item, tonight we learned Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is back in the hospital this time in New York. But again for a non-invasive procedure as it`s being called to clear a bile duct she`s expected to be out and well in a few days.

It`s a lot. Nothing our big three can handle as we start things off on a Wednesday night was Shannon Pettypiece, Veteran Journalist, Senior White House Reporter for us at NBC News Digital. Dr. Irwin Redlener Pediatrics, Physician and Clinical Professor at the School of Public Health at Columbia University, where he is also the Director of Columbia`s National Center for Disaster Preparedness. And Jeremy Bash, Former Chief of Staff at CIA and the Pentagon, former Chief Counsel to the House Intel Committee.

Good evening, and welcome to you all. And Shannon, I`d like to begin with. No briefing today because the President was on the road, not a peep from the Coronavirus Task Force. They have been invisible as a group of late. No mentioned by the President of the staggering death toll. Based on your reporting, is this just the way it`s going to be?

SHANNON PETTYPIECE, NBC NEWS.COM SENIOR WHITE HOUSE REPORTER: Well, inside the White House, the administration there is a big push to try and get messaging out specifically to the states that they see either experiencing a surge right now or on the cusp of seeing another surge. There`s about a dozen states, they`re watching very closely right now that they feel are at risk of becoming the next Florida or Arizona or California. So within the White House, within the administration, there was a big effort to get the message to the governors in those states, the mayors of the cities in those states and the public to follow the very basic principles that doctors have been trying to get people to follow for months now, the mask wearing, social distancing, avoid big crowds, don`t go to bars. That within the White House is acknowledged as the way to get out of this crisis that we are in.

There`s Dr. Birx has been pushing mayors and governors do these universal math mandates. Acknowledging that at this point, masks are the best way to get these cases under control and to get us to the point where we can have schools and sports and eat indoors again. So that`s what`s happening within the White House and behind the scenes and the White House is starting to push these doctors out more to do local media interviews, targeted interviews. But while the administration and the Coronavirus Task Force and the doctors are focused on governing, President Trump is clearly focused on the culture war issues, not the governing issues and when you see things like and this is how was explained to me by, you know, someone who`s one of the close advisor to the President, when you see things like tweeting out this hydroxychloroquine video of the doctor motive, the alien DNA and the demon spirits and all of that, that`s part of his culture war battle. It`s not about governing to him. It`s about this fight against the mainstream media that is -- that he perceives is trying to unfairly characterize hydroxychloroquine.

It`s about this culture war, about masks and independence and opening up the economy. That`s what he is focused on waging. And also, of course, trying to shift the attention to issues like crime and anarchy with sending these federal agents to Portland, and continuing to bring up this idea that the suburbs are going to be destroyed by people living in low income housing. He`s fighting a culture war. Other people in the administration are trying to govern to get this virus under control. And they clash when you see these contradictory messages like we are running into over and over again on these basic public health principles.

WILLIAMS: Dr. Redlener, Shannon, of course is 100% right. I know you signed up to fight disease and not a culture war. But here`s the question now that even mask wearing is caught up in a partisan culture war. And now that this virus right now is eating up so much real estate in our country, could you make a case that the danger we face right now is in its own way worse than say, March and April?

DR. IRWIN REDLENER, EXPERT ON PANDEMIC INFLUENZA: Yeah, of course. And what we`re playing now is a very lethal game of whack a mole, Brian, it`s not even a second wave, it`s just that it popped up, of course, and had a major epicenter consequence for America in the northeast and in New York City in particular. And now it`s in the Sun Belt and Phoenix and California and so on.

And a couple of points here, you know, the case, count right now is about 4,300,000 or so cases. But as Dr. Fauci pointed out, and the CDC confirmed, these are only the test confirmed cases, it`s actually probably 10 times that. So we`re dealing with about 45 million cases in the United States right now. And there`s no doubt that this death toll is going to rise to many hundreds of thousands of people have been saying, I wouldn`t be surprised we`ve reached 800,000 by the end of this year.

So we have just a massive problem going on here with a confluence of the public health concerns and the politicalization of this horrendous problem. You know, the issue about wearing masks has become so politicized and, Brian and I have talked about this before, you don`t even need a mag hat anymore to know where you stand. So if you`re defying wearing a face mask, the basic public health threat that we have here, you don`t need the mag hat. Everyone knows where you stand if you`re not wearing a face mask. This is the responsibility of the president United States. And it`s really just extraordinarily irresponsible.

WILLIAMS: Jeremy Bash in the frog boiling experiment that has become American life in 2020. Please note, no one was surprised today when Jonathan Swan got the president to answer that, no, he in fact, didn`t say to Putin, hey, are you paying bounties to kill our guys and Afghanistan? That elicited no surprise. I want to play this for you though. This is a woman who has spent her professional life studying former KGB agent Vladimir Putin. Here is Fiona Hill from today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

FIONA HILL, FORMER NSC SENIOR DIRECTOR FOR EUROPEAN AND RUSSIAN AFFAIRS: Who is looking to see what he can get out of it no matter who it is. I mean, clearly he wants to have a weaker U.S. president as a matter of who. And you know, he`ll be looking to see if that`s the kind of the case because the more that the U.S. is bogged down in its own internal contradictions and the weaker the president is domestically but also perceived internationally, the less likely it is for the U.S. to try to restore a leadership role.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: So Jeremy Bash, what might this mean for what`s going to be our second straight, susceptible to Russian interference presidential election?

JEREMY BASH, FORMER, CIA CHIEF OF STAFF: Well, Brian every hour that the President spends being commander-in-chief in a culture war, he`s abdicating his constitutional responsibility to be commander-in-chief for the national security of the United States. And there was no greater example, I think, in this interview that you referenced with Axios, in which the President acknowledged that he has not raised the issue with Vladimir Putin of Putin`s potential payments to the Taliban to target U.S. forces. So the President not only failed to rebuke the Russian leader, but in fact, he acquiesced to it. He is allowing it and he`s dismissing the credible reports the intelligence that did land on his desk, when he said it didn`t come to my desk. That`s a flat out lie. It came to his desk in a written presidential daily brief after the President claimed, well, I don`t read that, but it wasn`t even brought up orally. His aides did discuss it with him, and he has done precisely nothing, precisely nothing to push back on Russia and protect those men and women that he himself sends into harm`s way to defend our freedom.

WILLIAMS: And Jeremy while I have you explained to the good people watching why will make Putin very happy to withdraw 12,000 U.S. troops from Germany?

BASH: Well, to Fiona Hill`s point Brian, you know, the U.S. has enjoyed a strong relationship with Germany, Germany is a key NATO ally. And Vladimir Putin`s whole agenda is to disintegrate the U.S.-Europe Alliance, the NATO Alliance, the alliance between the United States and Germany. Germany, of course, was the country where the Berlin Wall fell, where the Iron Curtain was lifted after the reunification of Germany in 1991. So it`s very symbolic when Trump orders the withdrawal of 12,000 troops from Germany including 6000 out of Europe all together. This is exactly what Vladimir Putin wants. He thinks that makes America weaker. He thinks that makes Europe weaker, and he believes it makes Russia stronger.

WILLIAMS: Shannon, back to issues domestic is the extra benefit for those out of work going to just evaporate on Friday without anything to replace it?

PETTYPIECE: I mean, we`ve watched enough of these battles now between this administration and Congress, they`re really anything could happen. You know, it certainly seems like you have people whose financial livelihoods are on the line here. If this expires, you would think there`ll be a short term deal. But of course, remember that government shutdown when again, you had people`s financial livelihoods on the line, and they shut down the government for weeks on end.

You know, that`s still a lot of time between now and Friday in congressional hours. So there could be some short term deal and it sounded today like the President, Steve Mnuchin were open to the idea of something that just addresses eviction moratorium and extending that as well as some short-term unemployment. They got to get Democrats on the page. And right now there`s about a $2 trillion divide between where Democrats and Republicans are.

WILLIAMS: Dr. Redlener, the governor of Florida, Ron DeSantis said today, he would have no problem sending his children to school. CNN quickly pointed out he doesn`t have school aged children. Have you seen anything this week that would make you less reluctant to send your grandson to a classroom?

REDLENER: Well, there`s so much confusion about this, Brian. There`s actually no perfect solution to all this, except if we doubled or tripled the number of classrooms, which we do, by the way, we just take money. So we could actually separate people. And we can have ways of protecting teachers and staff and so on.

But right now, many, many jurisdictions are hitting towards this solution of, you know, random schedules for kids, some kids going one week and alternating that going the following week, or some children going one or two days a week and that`s it. And this is, you know, a solution but not a very good one because parents that are working and especially low income, and low income jobs, need to have a dependable regular school day for their kids.

So these solutions that are cropping up all over the country are generally inadequate in one way or another and it`s never going to satisfy everyone. So we`re in a big dilemma right now but the last thing we want to do is either expose children or their teachers to conditions that are unsafe. It`s fixable, but we need a lot more money and a lot more support from the federal government to make sure we have the money to create safe conditions in the classrooms.

That said, it is critical that kids get back on the educational trajectory. My grandchild will be fine one way or another, they can handle the remote access to school and they have the hardware and the access to the internet. But for many, many low income families, their children do not have access to the internet. They don`t have support for doing remote learning and most in many cases. So we have a huge problem where we`re getting the necessary educational trajectory for children against the public health conditions. And since we`ve done such a horrible job, and getting this epidemic under control, we`re left with no good choices at the moment with respect to returning to school unfortunately, Brian.

WILLIAMS: Much obliged to our three experts for starting us off tonight, Shannon Pettypiece, Dr. Irwin Redlener and Jeremy Bash. Thank you all.

Coming up for us a big voice from the smallest state in our union takes on Bill Barr, the titans of tech, and now a mask averse colleague from across the aisle with the coronavirus. We`ll talk to him next.

And later Joe Biden`s been waiting for his moment now he`s days away from revealing what will be his most consequential decision to date. We`ll preview the possible pics with Obama`s campaign manager as the 11th Hour is just getting underway on this Wednesday night.

WILLIAMS: So as we mentioned, Louie Gohmert tested positive for the coronavirus and he is actually, as we heard him say, blaming his mask wearing for it.

And Politico has this new detail. They received an email from one of the congressman aides. And it reads, thank you for letting our office know Louie tested positive for the coronavirus. When you write your story, can you include the fact that Louis requires full staff to be in the office including three interns, so that we would be an example to America on how to open up safely? When probing the office, you might want to ask how often we were often where people be rated for wearing masks.

For more on this and other topics we welcome to the broadcast congressman David Cicilline, the Rhode Island Democrat. He`s a member of both the House Foreign Affairs and judiciary committees.

Congressman, thanks very much for coming on. Do you worry about your exposure to Gohmert? And have you had your mask check for the coronavirus because that`s apparently how you get it?

REPRESENATATIVE DAVID CICILLINE, (D) RHODE ISLAND DUCIALLY COMMITTEE MEMBER: Yeah, it`s a really reckless thing to say. Of course, everyone should be following your public health guidelines and wearing a mask. Unfortunately, many of my Republican colleagues refused to do so. Thankfully the speaker put into place a requirement that everyone must wear a mask while in capital buildings that should not have been necessary. It really is a matter of not only public safety and public health, but it`s being responsible.

And Mr. Gohmert, unfortunately, was one of those people who didn`t wear a mask very often during committee hearings, endangering other people potentially, and really reckless behavior.

WILLIAMS: We played the following on the broadcast last night. We`re going to play it again. You were there for it. Here`s part of your exchange, with your apparent close personal friend, the Attorney General yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CICILLINE: Is it ever appropriate, sir, for the President to solicit or accept foreign assistance in an election?

BILL BARR, U.S. ATTORNEY GENERAL: It depends what kind of assistance.

CICILLINE: Is it ever appropriate for the president or presidential candidate to accept or solicit foreign assistance of any kind in his or her election?

BARR: No, it`s not appropriate.

CICILLINE: OK. Sorry, you had to struggle with that one, Mr. Attorney General.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: Congressman, why isn`t that a lay-up shot for him? Is that a close call?

CICILLINE: It`s -- it was shocking. Of course, it`s not a close call is always inappropriate to accept or solicit foreign assistance in a presidential campaign. The American people get to decide who will be the president United States, not any foreign government. It was shocking to hear the Attorney General first answer that by saying, it depends what kind of assistance. That`s a ridiculous claim.

And I think it was in part because he`s worried about the response from the President United States who we know has in fact accepted foreign assistance from 2016 solicited from Ukraine and the upcoming election and has publicly invited other foreign countries to come and help and study publicly. He would accept it.

So I think the Attorney General was actually afraid to answer the question the way he should have immediately and said, it is of course improper any legal for the president United States or any presidential to accept foreign assistance. And I think he finally realized that he had to finally acknowledge that that was the right answer. But it was very disappointing, but not surprising that he struggled with it.

WILLIAMS: Never a dull moment in front of your committee, you had the Four Kings of tech are the four horsemen depending on your persuasion today, the four largest tech firms in the country. Devil`s advocate is it their fault that they have grown so big their companies have grown so big and have the influence they have in American life? Or is that not the point?

CICILLINE: Well, it`s not the point. Look, they have grown and we began a hearing today that was really the culmination of a more than a year long investigation that has been done by the antitrust subcommittee, the first major antitrust investigation done by Congress in 50 years. These dominant technology platforms have enormous market power, really monopoly power. And today`s hearing really confirm. That that allows them to abuse competitors that allows them to favor their own products and services. It allows them to diminish innovation, and to really keep people on their platforms because they don`t really have any competition.

We have a long history in this country of battling democracy against monopolies. We have not done good antitrust enforcement, both Republican and Democratic administrations. Congress has not properly asserted its role in conducting oversight. But this is the beginning of a new era. This was a bipartisan investigation that began a year ago. Today`s hearing, I think there were tough questions by Republicans and Democrats really getting at the dangers of this kind of market power, the kind of concentration that these big large technology platforms have that allow them to harm consumers to really decrease innovation, to bully competitors, and to really behave like monopolies. And so we`re going to finish our investigation, prepare a report with a set of recommendations to get the digital marketplace working properly to bring real competition back into this space.

WILLIAMS: Congressman Cicilline with the great state of Rhode Island, thanks for working late. Thanks for having us in and sparing a couple minutes for our broadcast. Great to have you appreciate it very much.

CICILLINE: My pleasure. Thanks.

WILLIAMS: Coming up for us. Joe Biden says he`ll announce his VP pick within days. We`ll talk to Barack Obama`s former campaign manager about what we know about the shortlist.

(BEGIN AUDIO CLIP)

MICHELLE OBAMA, FORMER FIRST LADY: I think too many young people who question whether voting, whether politics is worth it.

BARACK OBAMA, FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT: Well, partly because they have been told the message is sent every day that government doesn`t work. But all government is us, collectively making decisions together.

(END AUDIO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: Michelle Obama kicked off the inaugural episode of her new podcast with a special guest who sounded a lot like the 44th president, their discussion focused on community and working together to change government. A few hours ago, the 45th president took a noticeably different route.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: They don`t love our country, in any way, shape, or form. They don`t love our country is no respect but there is by you. And there is by now 95 percent of our people, our people love our country and our people love our anthem and they love our flag.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: Back with us again tonight, David Plouffe, former Obama Campaign Manager, Senior Advisor to President Obama also is on the Board of Directors of the Obama Foundation. His latest work is "A Citizens Guide to Beating Donald Trump" which if nothing else, tells you which side of the political spectrum he is on.

Hey, David, this tweet from the president this morning. I`m happy to inform all of the people living their Suburban Lifestyle Dream, capitalized like it`s a magazine, title that you will no longer be bothered or financially hurt by having low income housing built in your neighborhood. Your housing prices will go up based on the market and crime will go down. He has rescinded the Obama-Biden Fair Housing rule.

David unless your dog is deaf, this is no longer dog whistle. This is stuff he is straight up saying out loud other than the base. Who is he going to attract with that?

DAVID PLOUFFE, FORMER OBAMA CAMPAIGN MANAGER: Right, Brian, he`s not disguising it anymore. It makes me think that the Republican Convention is going to be like a white power hour every night.

So, so first of all, Brian, it`s so true. I think Trump must have been briefed by his campaign team that he`s eroding in the suburbs. He`s losing what support he had Biden`s strengthening. And you know, rather than thinking, what could I change about my response to the pandemic, or the way I talk about issues, he`s just saying Biden`s going to get rid of the suburbs, and, you know, you`re going to have hordes of criminals in your community and on the person that keep you safe. No one`s buying, by the way, I`m not this wouldn`t have worked back in the 50s. Much less, you know, 2020. So it`s very puzzling to me.

So I think Trump at least now accepts that he`s having political problems in the suburbs, which could cost him a second term, but he has no earthly idea what to do about it, other than his ridiculous scare tactics which I think for the most part, people are tuning out.

WILLIAMS: David, I note the DNC named Mayor Bottoms, and Senator Duckworth, co-chairs of the upcoming convention, even while it may be on Zoom, people immediately wondered if that was a consolation prize of sorts, knowing you`re probably not going to answer this. I`m duty bound to ask you anyway, who would you like it to be? Who do you think it`s going to be?

PLOUFFE: Well, Brian, this is not just a dodge. I mean, Joe Biden went through this process in 2008. He was selected, he served in the job. So this is mostly about his partner in the White House, not as partner on the campaign trail. And so I think 90 percent of this will be who do I want serving by my side if I win, and so that`s much less about who helps me win a state which I don`t think really is a factor who was going to help you raise more money.

You want in the campaign, you know, somebody who`s going to do well in that one debate with Mike Pence, assuming there is one, someone who would give good speech, the day that they`re selected, somebody gives a good convention speech. That`s really the extent of it. And somebody who`s ready to be president on day one, and I think anybody that Joe Biden`s going to have on his really shortlist, I think will pass that bar. So I know that`s a boring answer. But that`s the truth.

I will say, I went through this process with President Obama. It is a very lonely decision for these people. So people like me who are advisor, you know, it`s the thing they were least interested in our opinion, and quite frankly, they listened to it. He listened to it, but he had to live with this decision.

So this is Joe Biden`s first executive decision. And it`s a very lonely decision, a very personal decision. But I`m sure he`ll get it right because he served in the job. And he knows that this is unusual times. He needs somebody who can help him deal with pandemic, getting a vaccine distributed, digging out of an economic recession will be luckily if we`re not in depression, rebuilding alliances, you know, protecting healthcare. So the task here is enormous. So he needs somebody who`s a great partner in terms of a counselor, but somebody who can take on MIDI projects.

WILLIAMS: Well, you put it that way. It sounds like an important choice that we will learn about just days from now. David Plouffe, thanks for having us in. Always a pleasure to have you. Thank you very much for coming on.

Coming up for us, four of the richest men in the world trying to defend their tech industry to lawmakers with why any of that matters and what we learned after this long day coming up.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JIM JORDAN (R), OHIO: I`ll just cut to the chase big techs out the gate conservatives.

REP. MATT GAETZ (R), FLORIDA: I believe it is in fact your company that is engaging in election interference. And it`s not just my view.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think at this point, it`s fairly obvious that technology platforms have been stifling Conservative News and opinions.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAMS: So that`s the one side, that`s what Republicans were focused on as they question four of the nation`s big tech execs today, but the purpose of today`s House hearing, as we heard in our earlier segment was to talk about antitrust issues.

The Times puts it this way, Democrats on the committee quickly dug into the issue of competition, citing documents obtained from inside the tech companies that they said showed their anti-competitive conduct.

For more and long last we welcome to this broadcast Scott Galloway. He`s a professor at the NYU Stern School of Business. I knew I was going to screw that up and the author of "The Four: The Hidden DNA of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google," also co-host of New York Magazine podcast Pivot alongside our friend, the technology journalist Kara Swisher.

Big fan. Thank you for coming on. And I hope it`s the first of many appearances and I`ll start with a devil`s advocate question in a pandemic. Why should Americans who may view Amazon as a lifeline during this time, who casually pick up their Apple phone, use it to Google something, use to hop on Facebook have baked all of this into their lives. Why was today important for them? Why should they care about this hearing?

SCOTT GALLOWAY, NYU PROFESSOR, STERN SCHOOL OF BUSINESS: First off, thanks for your generous words. It`s good to be with you, Brian. So I think that today was typically these things are more spectacle than historic. And I would argue that this was fairly historic and that this might have been the beginning of the end, big tech, as we know it. This was more confirmation of the 13 or the combination of a 13 month investigation over a million documents.

And these witnesses were really just props for the committee to basically go through all the reasons that they feel that these companies are suppressing innovation, avoiding taxes, crushing competition. So why should we care as citizens? I think our prices have gone up if you`re a parent, your prices have gone up in terms of teen depression because there`s no reason for Facebook to compete and put in place safeguards. If you`re an entrepreneur the fastest growing parts of our economy are dominated by Google, obviously prices have gone up. And if you`re a taxpayer, the most profitable companies in the world seem to have overwhelmed Washington and engage in massive tax avoidance.

So our prices which is typically kind of the measure for any trust have skyrocketed. So I think this was more historic and spectacle. I think this is the beginning of the end, as big tech as we know it, Brian.

WILLIAMS: So you and I are old enough to remember one phone company and you had to even buy the phone from that phone company until Judge Green came along and busted it up. Can I assume from your answer that in our remaining lifetime, we`re going to see real regulation and or busting up of some of these de facto monopolies?

GALLOWAY: I believe so. What was interesting o telling is before the hearings kicked off, you had tweets advocating to break these firms up from Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump. This is a rare bipartisan issue now.

Now, it felt like we went to committee hearings today. The Republicans want to break them up because of what they pursue -- Democrats want to break them up because what they feel are anti-competitive practices. But it`s rare that you see some sort of consensus now, regardless of why they want to break them up, there seems to be some consensus.

And you brought up AT&T, Brian, there`s few things our government seems to get right all the time and breaking up companies seems to be one of those things. When we broke up AT&T, there was the same nationalist argument. We need a national champion. We need a big company to make the requisite investments. Big is good. We broke these companies up and just 10 years later, these companies each were worth more than the original company and we unlocked incredible innovation and shareholder value, fiber, data cell, that it all ended up were lying dormant. PayPal spun from eBay is now worth multiple times more than the parent company.

So there`s a lot of great reasons to break up a company. It`s good for shareholders, it`s good for the tax base. It`s good for employees. The only thing that -- the only individual that it`s bad for is the CEO who wants to remain in front of Westeros, just not just not one of the seven rounds. So this is one of the few things that government always seems to get right is breaking up companies.

WILLIAMS: This is what we are trying to tell our viewers you will gain by listening to the podcast we mentioned. Scott Galloway, please come back on and talk about your point, your point on higher education that it`s become a very expensive streaming service these days. But please come back on the broadcast. Thank you for having us in and sharing a few minutes with us tonight.

GALLOWAY: Thank you.

WILLIAMS: Coming up, it`s a seven-month trip starting with tomorrow`s rocket launch. And when it lands, the whole world will be watching this little thing. The story when we continue.

WILLIAMS: So if you want to go to the moon in space terms, it`s relatively easy. If you push it you can be there in three days. Mars, something else entirely. Just the launch window opens once every 26 months. That`s when the orbits of Earth and Mars align.

So, tomorrow morning, weather permitting, NASA`s Mars rover will lift off from Cape Canaveral on its mission to Mars. It`s a hall. It takes about seven months to get there before the rover can begin its search for evidence of life. We get the full story tonight from NBC News correspondent Tom Costello.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

TOM COSTELLO, NBC NEWS CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Headed for Mars tomorrow, a new rover named Perseverance and boy is it loaded with cameras and probes and drills to collect soil and rock samples for a future trip to Earth. Even a microphone so we can all hear what Mars sounds like, but it`s the tiny helicopter or drone that`s getting the most attention. It`ll fly just 15 feet off the ground, surveying the Martian landscape.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: We`re shooting hoping to be like the Wright brothers moment. But on another planet at Mars. Yes, we`re extraordinarily excited.

COSTELLO: The Mars 2020 mission is headed for a cold dry crater wants an ancient lake where scientists hope to find signs that microbial life did or does exist. NASA Chief Jim Bridenstine.

JIM BRIDENSTINE, NASA ADMINISTRATOR: I`m not saying it was inhabited, I don`t know. But I can tell you this. It looked a lot like Earth about 3 billion years ago.

COSTELLO: This mission also laying the groundwork for eventual human trips to Mars.

ASAD ABOOBAKER, NASA INSTRUMENTS SYSTEMS ENGINEER: Getting to Mars, obviously with humans is very difficult surviving on Mars is very difficult. Getting back from Mars is very difficult.

COSTELLO: We often assign human qualities to our space probes envious of the places they go. Tomorrow, Perseverance is headed to Mars leaving us to wait and wonder. Tom Costello, NBC News, Washington.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WILLIAMS: And while it`s way too early for those of us on this shift lift off from Cape Canaveral, 7:50 a.m. tomorrow. Coming up, creepy packages from the other side of our planet arriving in American homes. Problem is no one asked for them. We`ll have the story after this.

WILLIAMS: Last thing before we go here tonight also happens to be our consumer news segment. People in at least 28 states over half the country have reported receiving small packages lately that they didn`t order. They usually come by mail in yellow or white envelopes or small pouches. They often have Chinese rights because they are from China. The packages contain seeds that no one in this country ordered. No one knows what they grow. No one wants to find out. Here is a portion of the reporting on this story from our NBC station in Chicago WMAQ.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

AMBER ECKERT, ILLINOIS RESIDENT RECEIVED MYSTERY SEEDS: This is the package it says it has jewelry.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The delivery from China showed up at Amber Eckert`s house in Wheaton.

ECKERT: I didn`t even think twice to open it. And I thought jewelry I mean even it kind of felt like maybe like a little chain or something. I thought what I ordered I don`t remember, what my husband`s buy.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Packed inside was a tiny bag of seeds that no one ordered.

ECKERT: It`s pretty weird. I figure the world feels upside down the way it is anyways, so to have these mystery seeds being sent out, who knows a little bizarre.

MARYANN BROWER, MINNESOTA RESIDENT RECEIVED MYSTERY SEEDS: This is so bizarre.

UNIDENTIDIED MALE: Similar seeds are ending up in mailboxes across the country.

BROWER: Getting seeds from China. It`s like what the heck is this, to be perfectly out of.

(END VIDOETAPE)

WILLIAMS: It straight up creepy and it`s believed to be an e-commerce tactic called brushing. It means someone gets your name and address from somewhere, usually a third party seller and is sending you something unsolicited to claim you as a customer so they can then post a bogus positive review for any product they wish.

As for the seeds, this is really important. They could be an invasive species. They could carry disease or agricultural blight or harm animals. Ideally, your state Agriculture Department would like to examine them and dispose of them for you.

But one firm request they`re making of people is don`t throw these in the trash, because they could take root in landfills. The experts are actually asking you to destroy them any other way. So smash them with a hammer bake them in the oven throw them in a fire.

Again creepy but there are now warnings posted in all 50 states to be on the lookout for these as they are arriving unsolicited every day. So be warned. And isn`t this story as the woman said perfectly in keeping with the year we are having so far.

That`s our broadcast on a Wednesday night. Thank you so very much for being here with us. On behalf of all my colleagues at the networks of NBC News, good night.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.
